Term.Title: About Balance of the Planet
Term.Text:
I want to make this game a lot better. I want to have better images. I want more links to references and resources. I want more background pages. I want to make it available for free on the Web, so that people can play it with a browser.

There is also a major improvement that I had originally planned that wasn't implemented in this version of the game. The biggest weakness of this game is that the calculations involve assumptions that different people will find objectionable. For example, how safe is nuclear power? There's a number in the game for that, but is the number too big or too small? Some people will say that it's too big; some will say that it's too small. Who's right?

In this game, I had to up with the best number I could based on my research. But I want to link each page to a special "formula page" that allows the player to adjust the numbers that control the equations. That way, you could decide for yourself exactly how safe nuclear power is, how cheap or expensive solar power is, how fast climate change is proceeding, how important economic growth is, and so on. This would immensely improve the game. All the basic data structures are in place to make this happen, but I had to leave them unused for now.

Another idea that I'd like to do is the provision of "biased versions" of the game. One version would use a set of numbers reflecting what an environmentalist might prefer; another version would present what a businessman might prefer.

If you know somebody who'd like to fund a proper version of this game, have them contact me at balance@erasmatazz.com

Term.Title: Absorption
Term.Text:
Molecules can ring like bells; every molecule has some basic frequencies that it resonates at. Their ringing frequences are much higher than bells. Many molecules have resonance frequencies that are in the same general ballpark as the frequencies that photons have.

Each photon has a color, and that color corresponds to a specific frequency (see the backgrounder on light).

Let's just suppose that we've got an innocent little photon flying through the atmosphere and it hits a molecule. If the molecule's natural frequency doesn't match the photon's frequency, nothing happens, and the photon flies right by as if the molecule wasn't there.

But if the molecule's natural frequency just happens to be close to the photon's frequency, then the molecule absorbs the photon. It gobbles up the photon and starts ringing at its frequency.

Molecules aren't exactly like bells: a molecule's ringing doesn't fade away naturally. Instead, after ringing for a tiny fraction of a second, the molecule changes its mind and disgorges the photon.

But there's a catch: the direction that it vomits out the photon at is NOT the same as the direction the photon was originally going; in effect, the molecule changes the course of the photon in a random way. The fact that it vomits out the photon in a random new direction is critical to the next step: the greenhouse effect.

Term.Title: Anti-Nukes
Term.Text:
Nuclear power is a complicated and difficult subject. But to some people – the anti-nukes – it's really quite simple: nuclear power is evil and dangerous. These people are mucking up the important public debate with irrational emotionalism.

Don't get me wrong: there is a respectable case against nuclear power. There are some very well-informed people who oppose nuclear power. But I have studied the subject for many years and my opinion is that the preponderance of evidence favors nuclear power, and the dangers of nuclear power are much overrated. I respect those well-informed people with whom I disagree – but I do disagree with them. Here are three bad reasons why some people oppose nuclear power:

Irrational fear of radioactivity: It is certainly understandable that people would fear the unknown, and few people have ever had the chance to familiarize themselves with the effects of radioactivity. Yes, radioactivity can definitely be dangerous: but so can electricity, automobiles, and household chemicals. In fact, each of these dangers kills many more people every year than radioactivity kills. But you aren't afraid of electricity, cars, or household chemicals, because you use them every day. You respect the dangers they impose, but you don't fear them. In the same way, a reasonable person should assess the dangers of radioactivity the same way that they might assess the dangers of electricity, cars, or household chemicals. A calm, rational assessment of the risks shows that the fearmongering of many anti-nukes is just wrong.

It's Big Business: Most of us have a healthy skepticism about the motives of big corporations. We're also pretty wary of Big Government, and Big Science doesn't warm the cockles of our hearts, either. And where do Big Business, Big Government, and Big Science come together? Right: in nuclear power plants. So all of our healthy, natural wariness is set on high alert when we consider nuclear power. There's nothing wrong with being skeptical about nuclear power – but skepticism is not the same thing as opposition. I encourage you to learn everything you can about nuclear power. Not just lots of anti-nuclear stuff, nor lots of pro-nuclear stuff. Read stuff from both sides so that you can make an independent decision. I list some links below (and in other places in this game) to help you find both sides of the issues.

It's what my friends believe: If you run around with a liberal crowd, you're probably opposed to nuclear power; if you run around with a conservative crowd, you're probably in favor of nuclear power. Don't you think that's kind of silly? I mean, what does your political preference have to do with the complicated technical issues of nuclear power? If you really want to be a good citizen, don't just follow the crowd: find out for yourself and make your own decisions based on the evidence you uncover. And don't get all your evidence from just one side: whatever your biases, make sure to carefully read a broad spectrum of sources.

If you do study the issue carefully, you'll learn that it's a complicated subject and it's easy to mislead people by telling only part of the story. Radioactive waste disposal is not a technical problem: we know how to do it safely. But it is a huge political problem. Given the fact that people are so jumpy about radioactivity, how can you dump all the radioactive waste from all over the country in just one place?

It shouldn't take you long to learn that nuclear power plants cannot explode like atom bombs; that's impossible, period. However, if they overheat, they can build up a bubble of hydrogen gas, and the hydrogen gas can explode. In fact, that happened three times at Fukushima.

Some people argue that nuclear power plants are so expensive that they don't make economic sense. That's only true when we saddle them with endless lawsuits that delay construction. If we just set clear regulations and let people get on with it, nuclear power plants would be cost-effective. They're not cheap, but they are still worthwhile. And yes, as people learn more about the technology, we can reduce some of the costs.

There is one argument against nuclear power that has some real substance. Nuclear power plants are like airplanes: operated properly, they're extremely safe. But it has taken us almost a hundred years to learn enough about airplanes to build up an entire community of pilots, mechanics, air traffic controllers, and lots of other people who are all exquisitely sensitive to safety. We have not had as much time learning about nuclear power plant operations. If everybody working at nuclear power plants were as well trained and as well paid as the people who keep airplanes flying, nuclear power plants would be just as safe as airplanes. But are they all, each and every one, really that good?

Term.Title: Automobile Safety
Term.Text:
Most people think that big cars are safer than small cars. There is some truth in this statement – but not much. The weight of a car is a minor factor in overall automotive safety.

Suppose that you're in a big car and you crash into a concrete abutment. That abutment isn't going to yield an inch. So what do you need for protection?

Let's compare two imaginary cars colliding with a solid concrete abutment. Both cars have the engine in the rear of the car. One car has five feet of solid steel armor plate in front of the driver; the other car has absolutely nothing in front of the driver. Which driver is safer?

Surprise, surprise, the answer is that they're both equally at risk. Why? Because the concrete is solid, and so when the car hits the concrete, it must stop in an instant. If you're the driver without any protection, your body crashes into the concrete at full speed. But if you're the driver with the huge armor plate, it's no different: your body still crashes at full speed, but this time it crashes into the armor plate instead of the concrete. It makes no difference whether you crash at 60 mph into solid concrete or solid steel: you're still squooshed.

What you need is not solid dead weight but cushioning. That's what the air bag is for, but it can provide only so much cushioning. What you really want is a front end that crumples up nicely in a collision. Look closely at the photograph: notice how the front end of the car is crumpling up neatly. All the energy that was in the moving car is being used to crumple all that metal. The whole front end is designed so that the maximum amount of metal must be bent in order for the front end to crumple. All that metal-bending absorbs lots of energy – energy that does NOT go into ripping apart your body. By contrast, steel armor plate doesn't absorb any energy – it just transmits it straight to your body.

The same thing goes if you hit a concrete abutment, a big tree, a telephone pole, or any other stationary object. Unless it gives way, you want lots of crumply cushioning. And it's just as important for sideways collisions or rear-end collisions.

There is one situation where having extra weight enhances your safety. If you crash head-on into another car, then if your car is heavier than the other guy's car, you'll be safer than the other guy. That's because the extra weight of your car forces his car to stop more quickly than your car, so his car must absorb more energy more quickly than your car. But there's a catch (there's ALWAYS a catch!): your greater safety is gained by making everybody else less safe. Because your car is heavier than other people's cars, any collision with your car has more destructive energy than a collision with a regular-size car. In other words, you're making the roads more dangerous for everybody else in order to make the roads safer for yourself. Isn't that selfish?

Remember also that big cars aren't as nimble as smaller cars, so it's easier to get into an accident in the first place with a big car. And of course, the most important factor in automobile safety is you, the driver. Being a careful driver will do far more to insure your safety than having a big car.

Adding it all up, the safety advantage of a big heavy car is pretty small.

Term.Title: Bagger 288
Term.Text:
This is the largest land vehicle on the planet, and it gets the worst mileage of anything! It is the Bagger 288, built in Germany to excavate huge seams of coal several hundred feet below ground. It simply eats through the dirt above the coal, exposing the coal. Then it collects the coal.

This is one big machine! It is 800 feet long and 300 feet high, weighs 13,000 tons, and boasts a top speed of nearly 0.4 mph. It is powered by electricity, requiring some 16 megawatts of power, which is about 20,000 horsepower. This translates into approximately 1,300 gallons of gasoline per mile, or about 0.0007 mpg.

The first Bagger 288 was built in 1979. The machine is typically used at a mine site for a number of years and then will move, under its own power, to a nearby mine site. This is a rather complicated process; it takes three weeks to move 10 miles. Along the way, they have to use bulldozers to prepare a level, smooth path for it. Where it crosses roads, they build a huge dirt "overpass" for the Bagger 288 to move over.. The trip costs $8 million, which is still cheaper than disassembling the machine, transporting the parts, and rebuilding it.

The manufacturer, Krupp, is now working on the Bagger 288z, a sporty version which will be available in Sapphire Blue, Firetruck Crimson, and Eco-Green. Racing stripes are optional. There were plans to organize a Gran Prix for competing Bagger 288s in the city of Monaco, but the city fathers, not wishing to see their city squashed, squashed the idea.

Term.Title: Behavioral Energy Conservation
Term.Text:
Energy conservation is not just a matter of new and better technology. One of the simplest and easiest ways to conserve energy is simply not to waste it! Americans waste enormous amounts of energy. Here are some of the things that you can do to reduce energy waste:
Turn the lights off when they're not needed. Some people just never remember to turn off the lights when they leave a room. A small room takes about one cent's worth of electricity to keep lighted for one hour. As time goes on, that cost will increase. It only takes a second to turn off the lights. It's just a matter of making a habit out of it.
Don't keep the house so warm in the winter This wastes enormous amounts of energy. Lots of Americans keep their houses at 72º in the winter. That's ridiculous. Europeans keep their houses much colder, and I myself keep my house at about 58º during the winter, saving enormous amounts of energy. I am especially sensitive to the cold, but I just wear long johns, heavy undershirts, a sweater, and two pairs of socks. If we're going to watch TV, my wife and I will sometimes use a little throw blanket that we keep by the couch. We also have covers for the windows to insure that we don't lose too much heat out the windows. Our house is big, and we live in the mountains where it gets pretty cold, and we have to use electricity for heating, but our monthly heating bill is only a $400 per month. This is about half what it cost the previous owners of the house.
Don't keep the house so cold in the summer. Hey, I hate sweltering temperatures just as much as the next guy, and I'm not about to suffer. We have house-wide air conditioning, but we seldom use it. In the first place, our house is surrounded by tall trees that block out much of the sunlight; that really keeps the place cool. Also, we cool ONLY the parts of the house we're actually using: my office during the day (it's upstairs where all the heat collects, and the computer equipment heats up the office); and the main bedroom for about an hour before bedtime. We open up the house at night when it's cool outside, and we even have window fans to push the hot air out of the top of the house, drawing cool air in through the lower windows. When morning comes, we button everything back up and the house stays cool throughout most of the day. If your house has an attic, an attic fan that automatically turns on when it gets hot will get you a lot more cooling per kilowatt-hour than an air conditioner will.

But easily the biggest way to save energy (and money!) is to cut down transportation costs. Assuming that you drive about 12,500 miles per year (a typical number for Americans), then you will spend approximately $6,000 per year on a small car and $10,000 per year on a large car or SUV. That means that buying the smaller car will save you $4,000 per year.

Another easy way to save money and energy is to drive less. There are lots of errands that need not be run today – put them off until you can consolidate them all into one trip. It's often faster to park once near the stores and walk from one to the next, but I know people who insist on driving their car from one end of the shopping center to the other end so that they don't have to walk its length. Use your bicycle more often: it saves lots of energy and it's better for your health. And why do you need to drive 50 miles to a restaurant when there are plenty of good ones much closer?

Americans use more energy per person than most other countries in the world. The average American uses more than four times as much energy as the average person elsewhere in the world. And it's not just because we're richer: we use twice as much as the average German or British citizen, and they're just as rich as we are. There are other countries that use more energy per capita than we do: oil-rich countries like Bahrain, Brunei, and Qatar, which have energy to burn (literally!); and perennially cold countries like Iceland and Canada, where people need lots of heat most of the year.

Term.Title: Bicycling
Term.Text:
Bicycling is not only the most energy-efficience way to get around; it's also the fastest way for short trips or in cities. Very roughly speaking, a bicycle is faster than a car for distances of about three miles inside a city – but it depends a lot upon the city. Hilly cities or cities with enormous amounts of parking lean more in favor of cars; but flat or dense cities definitely give a big advantage to bicycles.

In the typical American suburb, bicycles are faster than cars for trips of only a mile or so. But again, it depends a lot upon local conditions.

The single most important local condition is the provision of bicycle lanes. These set aside safe space for bicyclists so that cars don't run them down. The bike lane shown in the photograph is just about the best possible: it's wide, it's one-way (to go in the opposite direction, you use the bike lane on the other side of the street); and it's protected from cars by a separate parking lane. Note also that the bike lane is not part of the sidewalk; bicyclists and pedestrians don't mix together. This bike lane is in Copenhaagen, Denmark, one of the most bicycle-friendly cities in the world. Note the traffic on the street: there are fewer cars than bicycles and pedestrians!

Another important factor is the provision of bike racks for bicycle parking. Some cities have plenty of bike racks; some have none. People can't use their bikes if they don't have bike racks near their destination.

American cities and towns tend to be more "bike tolerant" than "bike friendly". They usually have some bike lanes along important routes, but usually these consist of nothing more than a painted stripe along the shoulder – and motorists usually ignore the bike lane (and police seldom cite them for doing so). That's why riding a bike in America is four times more dangerous than in northern Europe. However, the city of Portland, Oregon, has implemented serious bike lanes and as a result enjoys a much lower accident rate for bicyclists than anywhere else in America.

An interesting twist is provided by a variety of "bike sharing" services that stock bike racks with lots of specially marked bikes. You can use any bike you find, unlocking it at one place, riding it to your destination, and locking it on a bike rack there. There are many variations on the scheme; in some places, the bikes are free to use because the city and its merchants want to reduce traffic congestion. In other places, you pay money to get a special card that unlocks the bike from the rack; in other places, you put deposit coins in the lock. In still more cases, you use your credit card, but the charge is trivial; the primary purpose of the credit card is to provide some protection against theft. Again, Europe leads the way in such schemes; there are only a few in America.

Term.Title: Big Cars
Term.Text:
The typical big American car gets less than 20 mpg, an engine with at least 300 horsepower, and has a top speed in excess of 100 mph. It can go from 0 to 60 mph in six seconds or less. Impressive, no? But think about it for a minute: when was the last time that you needed to go over 100 mph? When was the last time that you needed to accelerate from 0 to 60 mph in six seconds? Probably not recently. Probably never. So why would you want a car that does things that you don't need it to do? Would you buy a car with two spare tires? How about a car with a horn that plays Beethoven's Fifth Symphony? Maybe you'd be interested in a car with a steering wheel that dices onions in seconds (and, if you act now, they'll throw in some Ginsu knives)? Why should you pay for features that you'll never use?

Many American cars are too big, too fast, too powerful – and too wasteful. People in Europe get along perfectly well with cars having half the horsepower of American cars. In fact, people all over the world are quite happy in much smaller cars than we use.

What's especially sad about this is that so many American families have two or even three cars. If you're going to have a lot of different cars, why not specialize: have a small car for commuting to work, and a big car for the whole family? Many families already do this, but there are still millions of families with multiple huge cars.

"But what about safety?" you might ask. "Aren't big cars safer than small cars?" Not really: in most cases, the weight of the car is not as important as how it's driven.

There's plenty of room for Americans to cut down on the size of their cars without suffering any serious inconvenience.

Term.Title: Billion Gallons of Gasoline Equivalent
Term.Text:
Because energy is so important to our world, we have lots of different units of measurement. Most physicists use Joules, but some physicists use electron volts; dieticians use calories; air conditioners use BTUs (British Thermal Units); the oil industry uses barrels; electricity is measured in KWh (kilowatt-hours); at coal plants they use tces (ton of coal equivalent); nuclear bombs are measured in tons of TNT equivalent.

Actually, the real reason there are so many ways to measure energy is to torture students. Did you know that there are 39.6832 million BTUs in 10 billion calories? Or that there are 0.0000002778 kilowatt hours in one Joule? There are, in fact 42 different conversion formulas for all these units of energy, so teachers love to make test questions like "How many gallons of gasoline (each containing 132 megaJoules) would it take to equal the destructive force of a 1 megaton hydrogen bomb, when one ton of TNT contains 4 billion Joules?" Test questions like these take lots of mental busywork but no real thinking.

Obviously, I didn't want to use lots of different units of energy in this game; I had to pick one and use it for all forms of energy. I decided that the form of energy that most people have a feeling for is a gallon of gasoline. You really wouldn't want to get a feeling for one KWh of electricity, because the only way to do that is to get yourself electrocuted. For the same reason, you don't want to get a feeling for the energy content of a ton of TNT. And who wants to dig through a ton of coal? So a gallon of gasoline it is.

Of course, you don't get gasoline coming out of the electricity socket, and you don't burn gasoline to heat your home. So we're really talking about the energy equivalent of a gallon of gasoline. For all you nerds reading this, here are the equivalents. One gallon of gasoline has the energy equivalet of 132 megaJoules, 132 thousand BTUs of heat, 37 KWh of electricity, or 31 million calories. Big deal.

The amounts of energy humankind uses are so high that we end up talking about billions of gallons of gasoline, so the standard unit of energy in this game is a billion gallons of gasoline equivalent. That's as much as 30 kiloton bomb, or half of the amount of electricity generated by China's huge Three Gorges Dam in one year. It would take five supertankers to hold that much gasoline.

Because "billion gallons of gasoline equivalent" is such a long, tiresome, tedious phrase to read, I'll just get snappy and call it a BgOge, which is pronounced "big oge", because it really is a lot of energy.

Term.Title: Biomass
Term.Text:
This is new snazzy, high-tech term for "burning old dead stuff". We produce all sorts of stuff that we can't otherwise use. The most abundant source of biomass is the stuff left over from lumber production. When loggers cut down trees for lumber, there's a lot of wood that isn't used for lumber: all the branches (called slash), the bark, and various edges and loose ends of wood. This stuff goes into a huge Osterizer thing that chops it all up into chips; the chips can then be burned to make electricity. We can also burn some of the stuff that's left over from farming.

Another way to use biomass is to chemically process it to make burnable methane gas; this works well with rice hulls (the stuff that's left over when we harvest rice) and corn stalks.

Term.Title: Breeder Reactor
Term.Text:
99.3% of the uranium we dig out of the ground is useless as a source of nuclear energy; only 0.7% is usable. The difference is that uranium comes in three isotopes: U234, U235, and U238. Almost all of the uranium in the ground is U238; the rest is U235, with a tiny amount of U234. The U238 (the most abundant form) can't fuel a nuclear reactor, because it doesn't make the right kind of nuclear reactions. The U235 is the good stuff, so we have to separate the U235 from the U238. We do this with a special technology that's super-high-tech and super-secret, because you can make uranium for nuclear bombs with it – in fact, possession of that technology is the key to building nuclear bombs. You still need the technology to make fuel for nuclear reactors, but you don't have to concentrate the U235 as much. To make fuel for nuclear reactors, you need to concentrate the U235 from 0.7% to 3%, but to make bombs you need to concentrate it to 90%. This is all very expensive.

Wouldn't it be nice if we could somehow use the U238 for fuel for our reactors? We have tons and tons of that stuff lying around left over after we separate out the U235. It turns out, there's a way to utilize U238. If you hit it with lots of neutrons, it will convert into plutonium 239, which can be used for fuel in nuclear reactors. The problem is, you need gazillions of neutrons to convert U238 into Pu239. Where you gonna get gazillions of neutrons?

Answer: on the sides of a nuclear reactor! You see, nuclear reactors rely on a nuclear reaction in which one U235 nucleus splits into pieces, releasing gobs of energy and three extra neutrons. We need just one of those neutrons to hit another U235 nucleus to keep the chain reaction going; that leaves two extra neutrons, which fly out of the reactor and get lost. That's what gives us the our source of neutrons. We just pack lots of U238 around the sides of the reactor, and some of those extra neutrons will hit U238 nuclei and convert them into Pu239 nuclei.

Here's the really wild thing about this design: it will generate more usable fuel than it burns. In other words, we can set up a breeder reactor with a load of fuel, and it will generate enough fuel to keep itself going forever – with plenty of extra fuel to use in other reactors! It's like a car that manufactures its own gasoline as it runs!

This is not magic; we're not getting something for nothing. Here's an analogy: suppose that it's a rainy night and you're trying to get a campfire going. You've got plenty of wet wood, but it won't burn. But you do have just enough dry wood to get the campfire burning well. So you pile up wet wood around the fire, and the heat of the fire dries out the wet wood as it burns. If you set it up properly, you can dry out wood faster than you burn it, manufacturing extra dry wood for later.

If you know anything about technology, you should always ask, "What's the catch?" There are two nasty catches with breeder reactors. The first catch is that you're making plutonium, which is just about the nastiest stuff in the world. It's extremely dangerous; just a tiny mote of plutonium inside your lung will cause lung cancer. Worse, it's perfect stuff for making bombs, because it's easy to concentrate and purify – you don't need all that high-tech top-secret, expensive technology to get bomb material. You just do some chemistry to it and voila! – lots of stuff for making nuclear bombs.

"Big deal", you say, "we don't need any more nuclear bombs, we've got too many already." That's true – but we're not the ones to worry about. What if, say, some nasty country that hates us gets its hands on a breeder reactor? It will start generating lots of plutonium and making bombs.

There are already too many countries with nuclear bombs – we don't want any more. So about forty years ago we set up something called the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty – the NPT. It's a simple deal: any country that signs the treaty promises never to make bombs; in return, we promise that we will let them have any and all peaceful nuclear technology that we are using. Almost all the countries in the world have signed the NPT. That's good, right?

But suppose that we start using breeder reactors commercially. That means that breeder reactors are peaceful nuclear technology, which means that any country that signed the NPT can demand that we sell them the breeder reactor technology so that they can have breeder reactors. Once they have working breeder reactors, it's all too easy for them to extract the plutonium and start making bombs on the sly – and there's not much we can do to prevent them from doing that. In other words, breeder reactors plus NPT equals proliferation! How's that for a catch?

But that's only the first catch. The second catch involves safety. Generation II reactors – the kind that we use right now – are really quite safe; even if you hit them with a record-setting earthquake and a monster tsunami, they do a pretty good job of protecting the public from danger. Breeder reactors aren't quite as safe. In the first place, they can't use water as a coolant; they have to use things like molten lead or molten sodium to cool the reactor. Liquid sodium burns if exposed to the air. It's one thing to have radioactive water leaking out from a nuclear power plant; if instead it's liquid sodium leaking and burning, that makes matters more complicated. We don't have much experience with these exotic cooling systems, so it's difficult to be certain that they'll be safe.

There's another concern. It is theoretically impossible for a Generation II nuclear power plant to explode like a nuclear bomb. That's not the case with breeder reactors. Under some conditions, it's theoretically possible for a breeder reactor to suffer a nuclear explosion. You can be certain that the designers of these reactors have come up with all sorts of clever schemes to make certain that this could never actually happen, but again, we don't have a lot of operating experience with breeder reactors, so we can't be sure.

Term.Title: Carbon Capture Technology
Term.Text:
Here's a bright idea: instead of sending the combustion gases from a coal power plant into a smokestack and then into the atmosphere, why not pump them deep into the ground where they can't do any harm? This idea is called "carbon capture and storage". We start with the "flue gases" – the stuff that would normally go up the smokestack and out into the atmosphere. Instead, we pipe those flue gases to a huge cooling chamber where we cool them down and then send them down a big pipe to a location where they are pumped under high pressure deep into the ground. We have to carefully select the place where we bury the flue gases, because we don't want them to leak out. Fortunately, there's a good use we can put these flue gases to. If we pump them into the ground near a big oilfield, they'll help push the oil into our oil wells where we can get it. While the basic technology for carbon sequestration has been around for a while, it is still expensive. Moreover, it takes a lot of energy to do all this cooling and pumping: between 25% and 40% of a coal plant's output. Thus, carbon sequestration technology decreases the amount of energy we can get from coal. There are currently four large carbon sequestration facilities in the world, which together sequestrate about 4.5 million tons of CO2 every year.

If you want to sound like you know what you're talking about, call it carbon capture and sequestration. If you want to sound like an expert, call it CC&S

Term.Title: Carbon Cycle
Term.Text:
There are lots of things that emit carbon dioxide into the air. Many of the chemical reactions going inside your body consume oxygen and release carbon dioxide. When you inhale, oxygen from the atmosphere enters your lungs and mixes into your blood cells, which carry it to every cell in your body. Meanwhile, all the carbon dioxide produced by those cells mixes into your blood, which carries it to the lungs. There it moves into the air that you exhale. So you inhale oxygen and exhale carbon dioxide. The same thing goes for every animal and insect on this planet.

If the world had only animals, we'd use up all the oxygen. But plants do the reverse: they take carbon dioxide out of the air and break it up to get the carbon they need. The oxygen that's left over just gets dumped into the air.

Some of the carbon that the plants use gets eaten by animals; some gets buried in the soil; some gets eaten by bacteria when the plants rot. Most of the carbon that's eaten eventually gets back into the atmosphere when the animals or bacteria release carbon dioxide. If that plant material gets buried under sediments and ends up deep underground, most of it eventually forms oil, coal, or natural gas.

The ocean also participates in the carbon cycle. It absorbs some of the carbon dioxide to make carbonic acid; this causes ocean acidification.

Thus we have a huge process called the carbon cycle. Carbon goes round and round, from atmosphere to plant to animal and back to the atmosphere. This cycle was in a nice stable equilibrium until we humans came along and started burning stuff, putting a lot more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. The total amount we put in is small potatoes compared to the size of the overall cycle. But it was in balance before we came along, and by butting in, we altered the balance. Beforehand, about 200 gigatons of carbon dioxide flowed into the atmosphere and back out every year, for a net change of zero. We added about 6 measly gigatons – but it was all going in, with none coming out. So every year, 206 gigatons flowed into the atmosphere, and only 200 gigatons came out. Do this long enough, and pretty soon you get a whole lotta gigatons in the atmosphere.

Some climate change deniers ("pants on fire!") like to say that the amount we put into the air is just too tiny to make a difference. Suppose that I were to hack into the bank account of one of these deniers and put in a little virus that stole just one cent of every dollar that he deposited into his account. That's only one-hundredth as much as he's adding to his account. But he's also taking money out of his account, and the overall account was in balance – until I hacked it. Now I'm steadily draining it away, and eventually he'll go broke. A small, steady change to a system that was in equilibrium will eventually alter it big-time. That's what we humans are doing to the atmosphere.

Term.Title: Chernobyl
Term.Text:
The accident at Chernobyl in 1986 was far and away the most serious accident at any nuclear power plant. The magnitude of the disaster can be grasped by a few numbers. The first is the number of deaths attributable to the accident. There is considerable controversy regarding this number; estimates range from a low of 4,000 to a high of over a million. My own study of the accident leads me to conclude that the most likely value is about 10,000 deaths. The second number is the total economic cost of the accident, which is more reliably estimated at something over $200 billion. The third number is the amount of land still uninhabitable 25 years after the accident: 6,000 square miles. Initially about 120,000 people lived in this zone; now only a few stubborn squatters remain. About the only upside is that wildlife, unhindered by human interference, has grown enormously in the area.

The accident was caused by a combination of poor design and truly idiotic behavior on the part of the operators. Ironically, the accident was triggered by an incompetently performed safety experiment. The experiment had been designed and developed over the course of several years, and had already been performed, unsuccessfully, a number of times.

The fundamental cause of the accident was a failure to abort the experiment after the conditions deviated from the planned experimental parameters. Instead, the fools running the experiment thought that they could improvise. You don't improvise with a 4,000 MW nuclear reactor.

The catalog of mistakes they made would make Homer Simpson blush with embarrassment. Their basic failure was not realizing that nuclear reactors can't be switched on and off like light bulbs. They must be brought up to full power in a smooth linear process; even more important, the process of shutting a reactor down must be done cleanly. Instead, these morons kept jiggling the control rods up and down, trying to get the exact power level they needed for the experiment. It's as if the pilot of an airplane coming in for a landing kept jerking the nose of the plane up and down trying to stay on the prescribed flight path instead of just coming in smoothly. And guess what? When you jerk a reactor around, it doesn't behave the way you expect it to.

To make a long story short, the reactor blew up. There were several explosions. One was a steam explosion and the other was probably a small nuclear explosion. When it blew up, highly radioactive chunks of the reactor shot up into the air and crashed to earth all around the plant. Then the graphite moderator caught fire and burned furiously, sending up intensely radioactive smoke that spread all over Europe.

Much of the blame, though, goes to two crucial flaws in the design of the plant. In the first place, it was a graphite reactor. These are powerful and physically efficient reactors, but they are intrinsically unsafe, because extremely hot graphite burns like a demon when exposed to oxygen. The plant operators were sure that there was no way that oxygen could get to the graphite – until the explosion. Once the graphite caught fire, there was nothing that could be done to stop it. No western nation has ever permitted the construction of a large graphite reactor because they are intrinsically unsafe. The only graphite reactors built in the West have been small research reactors.

The second crucial flaw was the absence of a containment structure. All Western reactors are built with huge containment structures – concrete shells ten feet thick with enormous amounts of huge steel rebar inside. The Soviets thought they didn't need no stinkin' safety features like containment structures. So when the reactor at Chernobyl exploded, there was nothing to stop all that radioactivity from going right out the roof and into the atmosphere.

The lousy safety standards of the Soviet nuclear industry were well known in the west. When somebody first told me of the Chernobyl accident, my reaction was, "Well, it finally happened." I wasn't the least bit surprised.

Term.Title: Clean Coal
Term.Text:
Let's face it: coal is the filthiest, most environmentally destructive source of energy on the planet (except for burning tires). People have been working on ways to clean up coal burning for decades now, and some of the technologies are already in use, while others are still years away.

Electrostatic precipitators are one of the oldest cleanup technologies. Do you recall how little bits of paper and fuzz will be attracted to a static-y wool sweater when you first put it on? Static electricity attracts tiny things, and the tinier they are, the better it attracts them. So they set up a bunch of metal plates and charge them up to a few thousand volts and run the smoke from the burning coal through them. The tiny smoke particles stick to the plates, so the smoke coming out has fewer particles. These devices typically catch more than 99% of the particulates. Remeber, though, that we burn so much that we still get a lot particulates going out the smokestacks: coal plants all over the world release about 10 million tons of particulates each year.

Scrubbers: This technology sprays a mixture of water and limestone through the outgoing smoke to chemically capture some of the worst pollutants. The good news is that these things are pretty good: the best of them capture most of the sulfur dioxide. The bad news is that the chemical reaction that absorbs the sulfur dioxide also releases even more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. Oops!

Coal gasification: The idea here is to refrain from burning the coal in the first place. Instead, we pulverize it and spray high-temperature steam over it. This triggers a chemical reaction that produces a gas containing carbon monoxide and hydrogen, and black icky sludge. The carbon monoxide is poisonous but it burns along with the hydrogen, releasing only carbon dioxide and water. How's that for clean? Of course, there is the little matter of the billions of tons of black icky sludge that we still have to get rid of, but at least it's all on one place, so we can dispose of it properly.

Term.Title: Coal Liquifaction
Term.Text:
During World War II, the Germans could never get enough gasoline. Most of what they had came from Romania, and when the Red Army captured that area in 1944, the Germans no longer had a source of gasoline. However, their tanks and planes didn't come grinding to a halt; they had figured out a way to make gasoline from coal, which they had plenty of. This process was not cheap, but it worked and was able to keep the German armies in operation for another year.

Since then, there have been many attempts to improve on the process of converting coal into gasoline. In the first place, we have so much coal that, if we could convert it into gasoline, we wouldn't have to worry about gasoline supplies for a long, long time. In the second place, converting filthy coal into cleaner gasoline should permit us to trap all the nasty pollutants at the factory, making it easier to keep them out of the environment.

There is one thing about coal liquifaction that has always mystified me: why isn't it called "coal liquification"?

Term.Title: Climate Change
Term.Text:
Although "Global Warming" is the term you hear most of the time, it's not the best term, because it's misleading. Scientists prefer the term "Climate Change". Sometimes you'll read about "Anthropogenic Climate Change" – that means "climate change caused by people". "Anthropogenic" is just hoity-toity for "caused by people". If you sneeze and get snot all over the place, call it "Sneezogenic Snot" and perhaps people will be so impressed that they won't mind.

What's wrong with the term "Global Warming"? Well, in the first place, the warming won't show up everywhere. It'll be really strong in the polar regions (it is already wreaking havoc around the Arctic), but around the equator, people won't notice much increase in temperature at all. However, they will notice other effects, such as changes in when and how much rain they get. Some areas of the planet will end up drier, while other areas will end up wetter. Some areas will experience more storms and flooding, while other areas may end up with fewer storms and flooding. The sea level will rise, and that will affect everybody.

Although the average temperature for the earth as a whole will rise, there are so many other effects, and they're spread so widely, that it's better to call it "climate change".

Anthropogenic climate change really is easy to understand with just a little science background, so if you want to learn how it works, start here.

You may have heard some people claim that climate change is all a big hoax, that it's not real. There's no nice way to say this: those people are liars. They deny climate change for political reasons, not scientific ones.

Term.Title: Concentrated Solar Thermal Energy
Term.Text:
A thermal power plant uses a source of heat to make electricity. There are plenty of ways to make heat: burning coal, oil, or natural gas, or by nuclear reactions, or by tapping the geothermal heat of the earth. We can also use sunlight as a source of heat for a thermal power plant; there are several ways to to do this.

The most commonly used technology uses a parabolic trough. To visualize this system, start by thinking of a big pipe maybe ten feet in diameter. Cut it in half lengthwise so that you get a long trough that has a cross-section that's a half-circle. Next, imagine changing the shape so that the cross-section is a parabola instead of a half-circle. Make the inner surface of the parabola shiny like a mirror. Lastly, mount a small pipe in the place that was once the center of the big pipe.

Now put this contraption outside in the sun, running from east to west. The sunlight will be focused by the mirror onto the little pipe, which will get really hot. Pump water through that little pipe and the water will get really hot, so hot that it will boil into steam. Let the steam go through a turbine connected to a generator, and voila! Electricity!

But there's another way to make electricity from sunlight: build a tall tower with a big black water container at the top. Then set up acres of mirrors around it, each one at a different angle to reflect sunlight directly onto the water tank at the top of the tower. All that sunlight focused on the water tank gets the water so hot that it boils into steam. Send the steam to a turbine, yada, yada, yada, and you've got electricity!

But wait! There's more! Ginzu knife solar generators! No, I'm kidding... but there is another way to make solar electricity. It uses parabolic mirror dishes (like big radar dishes) that focus sunlight onto a small Stirling engine, which makes electricity.

Term.Title: Condenser
Term.Text:
Water from warm air naturally condenses on the surface of any cold object. This happens whenever the object is colder than the air. So imagine what happens when you take something reasonably cool, like a pipe filled with cool water, and blow superheated steam over it. The steam will condense into water. If you keep pumping more cool water into the pipe, so that it stays cool, and more steam against it, then you'll get lots of water condensing.

This is how a condenser in a power plant works, but it's done on a humongous scale. We pump hundreds of gallons of cool water into it, and pipe enormous amounts of steam into it, the steam condenses into water, and we get lots of water coming out the bottom. Think about it: this is exactly the opposite of what the heat source in a power plant does. The heat source boils water into steam, and the condenser condenses steam back into water.

Now, when water boils into steam, it expands to 1700 times its regular volume; when steam condenses into water, it contracts to just 1/1700th of its volume. So the steam going into the turbine is at very high pressure, while the steam coming out of the turbine is at much lower pressure because the condenser is shrinking all that steam back into water. That huge difference in pressure is what makes the turbine turn so fast. The high-pressure steam is pushing really hard to get to the low-pressure steam area.

"Hold it right there!" I hear you say. "Where do you get all the cool water that goes into the condenser?" That requires a hyperbolic cooling tower

Term.Title: Controlling Reactions
Term.Text:
A nuclear power plant uses nuclear reactions to generate heat, but the uranium in a nuclear power plant is not squeezed together tightly enough to detonate like a nuclear bomb. Instead, the uranium fuel is made of little pellets that are stacked into fuel rods; bunches of fuel rods grouped together (with space between them) make up the core of the reactor. We can control the speed of the reactions by shoving special control rods in between the fuel rods. The control rods are made of elements that love to gobble up neutrons. So when we put the control rods down into the reactor, between the fuel rods, they block neutrons from moving from one fuel rod to the next, which cuts down on the number of nuclear reactions taking place. By moving different control rods up or down, we can precisely control how much heat the reactor produces.

But there's always a catch, and with nuclear reactors, the catch is that the uranium atoms aren't the only things inside the reactor that are making energy. You see, when a uranium nucleus fissions, it breaks into smaller nuclei. Now, if you carry out a scientific experiment by lining up a bunch of glasses and hitting each one with a hammer, you will observe (if you haven't lost an eye to flying shards of glass) that the glasses don't break up the same way each time. They break up into different shaped pieces of glass. Uranium atoms are the same way: they break up into different smaller nuclei.

Sometimes we get lucky and those smaller nuclei are normal, everyday nuclei. But many times the smaller nuclei are not normal; they're like mutants. They're radioactive, which means that they're just not put together right. They'll sit there for a few microseconds, or a few minutes, or a few decades, and then, for no reason at all, they'll fission, just like the uranium nucleus did. When they fission, they release lots of energy and – surprise, surprise – more neutrons! Those neutrons then fly off to break up more uranium nuclei, so the reactor continues to generate heat even after you've turned it off!

Term.Title: Costs of Nuclear Power
Term.Text:
The worst problem with nuclear power plants is that they're hideously expensive. There was a time when it seemed that they would produce oodles of power cheaply, but as the years rolled by and safety problems arose, people had to put more and more safety equipment on, raising the price. Worse, the plants had be built slowly and carefully, with careful inspections at each stage of construction. If it wasn't perfect, they'd have to tear out the defective sections and do them all over again. This slowed things down even more. Nowadays it can take ten years to build a nuclear power plant.

The base price of a nuclear power plant is a few billion dollars. However, all that money has be spent building the plant, before it starts earning any money. So the people building the plant have to borrow, say, $2 billion to get started. Can you imagine the interest costs on $2 billion? They run about $100 million per year. So if it takes 10 years to build the plant, you end up paying a billion dollar just for interest costs, raising the cost from $2 billion to $3 billion.

It gets worse. Every time there's a problem anywhere, it delays construction. When you're paying interest of about $30,000 every single day, delays of a week here and a week there start adding a lot of interest costs.

Then there's the uncertainty factor. Banks like safe investments. If they think that something might go wrong with the project, and they might not get their money back, they raise the interest rate. If the banks decide to charge you 6% interest instead of 5% interest, that addition 1% will add an extra $100 million to your costs.

The banks have good reason to worry: they may trust you, but how do they know that the government won't kill your project? The accident at Fukushima caused Germany to decide not to build any more nuclear power plants. Anybody who had spent money developing a new nuclear power plant lost all their money. Is politics predictable? Are you willing to bet $2 billion on the predictability of politics?

Term.Title: Deniers
Term.Text:
Fifty years ago evidence began to emerge showing that smoking is harmful to your health. The tobacco industry denied this strenuously and insisted that there was no scientific proof that smoking is bad for your health. For years they paid some scientists to deny the truth and publish scientific papers questioning the research that showed how harmful smoking can be. It took decades, but science eventually overcame the lies, and nowadays only cranks say that smoking isn't harmful to your health

But now we have the same thing all over again, only this time it's with climate change. Once again there are big companies (oil companies instead of tobacco companies) that are spending lots of money trying to confuse people about the truth. Once again there are people who put politics ahead of science and deny climate change. Once again the media are full of contradictory claims about a scientific subject. Once again the public doesn't know what to think.

The best way for you to figure all this out for yourself is to study the science for yourself. To understand it properly, you'd probably need to study it in college for at least four years, and even then you'd just know the basics. To really understand it well, you'd have to devote at least ten years of your life to studying all the science. Whos' got time for that?

There are four steps you can take to make your own informed decision. The first step is to read through the very brief materials here in this game.

The second step is to read the best brochure I've ever found on climate change. It's from the National Academy of Sciences and is free to download right here.

The third step is to read some of the better blogs. The blog I recommend for beginners is Climate Denial Crock of the Week. You can find a good debunking of the lies coming from the deniers at Skeptical Science. If you want to get really down and dirty, you can read what real scientists are talking about at Real Climate.

The fourth thing you can do is trust the best scientists in America. Denialists like to say that there's disagreement among scientists about climate change, but that's a lie. The National Academy of Sciences was set up nearly 150 years ago to provide Congress with reliable advice on scientific matters that might affect public policy. In 150 years, the National Academy of Sciences has issued hundreds of reports to Congress, and in all that time, there has never been a single statement in any report to Congress that was later found to be untrue. These folks have a perfect track record! And if you want to know what they have to say about climate change, just read the brochure I described in Step 2.

But maybe you don't want to trust the American National Academy of Sciences. OK, that's fine. Pick a country, any country; if it has a national academy of science of its own, then it has endorsed the idea of anthropogenic climate change. Here are the countries with national academy of sciences that have done exactly that: Australia, Belgium, Brazil, Cameroon, Canada, China, France, Ghana, Germany, Indonesia, Ireland, Italy, India, Japan, Kenya, Madagascar, Malaysia, Mexico, Nigeria, New Zealand, Poland, Russia, Senegal, South Africa, Sudan, Sweden, Tanzania, Turkey, Uganda, United Kingdom Zambia, and Zimbabwe. The climate change deniers will jump on the fact that this list leaves out such countries as Andorra, Liechtenstein, The Gambia, and Afghanistan...

Still not convinced? How about this list of scientific and professional organizations that have published resolutions in support of the theory of anthropogenic climate change: American Association for the Advancement of Science, American Chemical Society, American Insitute of Physics, American Physical Society, Australian Institute of Physics, European Physical Society, European Science Foundation, Federation of Australian Scientific and Technological Societies, American Geophysical Union, European Federation of Geologists, European Geosciences Union, Geological Society of America, Geological Society of London, International Union of Geodesy and Geophysics, National Association of Geoscience Teachers, American Meteorological Society, Australian Meteorological and Oceanographic Society, American Association of People Who Go Crazy Reading Long Lists, Canadian Foundation for Climate and Atmospheric Sciences, Canadian Meteorological and Oceanographic Society, Royal Meteorological Society, World Meteorological Organization, American Quaternary Association, and the International Union for Quaternary Research.

Term.Title: Different Volts for Different Folks
Term.Text:
One of the benefits of the grid is that it allows us to move electricity from places that have extra to places that don't have enough. This is valuable because it allows us to average out all the little bobbles and variations in the supply of and demand for electricity.

It's sort of like a potluck dinner: everybody brings something different to the meal and eats something different. If there are enough people participating, then it all pretty much averages out. There'll probably be plenty of food to meet the different tastes of different people.

This is really valuable when we start bringing in intermittent sources of electricity like solar and wind. These sources don't always provide the right amount of electricity at the right time, but if we hook them into a big enough grid, there'll probably be enough electricity from them and other sources to average out nicely.

But there is a limitation on the usefulness of the grid: transmission losses. The longer the transmission line, the higher the loss of electricity. So it really wouldn't be practical to ship solar electricity from Arizona to New York: we'd lose too much of the electricity moving it that far. Roughly speaking, the typical transmission line is good for moving power only about 500 miles. Any further than that and you start losing too much electricity.

Let's get back to the example of the pot luck dinner. Suppose that there were no cars. People couldn't travel very far, so the only people coming to the pot luck would be your closest neighbors. With that small a group, the pot luck might not work out well. Mrs. Jones and Mrs. Pederson would both bring their potato salad, and there'd be nothing good to eat. But with cars, more people would come, bringing a larger variety of dishes. Suppose that we had transporters that allowed people from all over the planet to come instantly. Then we'd get a huge pot luck with all kinds of different dishes from different countries. Wouldn't that be a great pot luck? The lesson is that the greater the distance you can reach, the better things work out. And it's the same way with electricity: the further we can economically transmit electricity, the more efficiently the whole grid works.

But it all depends on how high the voltage is. Higher voltages can travel further. Which brings us to a new technology that could be more important to solar and wind than anything else: HVDC (High Voltage Direct Current).

Term.Title: Diminishing Returns
Term.Text:
Suppose there's a cute {boy|girl} that you'd like to impress. So you buy {him|her} a {videogame|book} as a present. {He|she} is pleased with the present. So you decide to buy {him|her} another present, then another, and another, and another. By the fifth present, {he|she} isn't so impressed, and by the tenth present, {he|she} isn't the slightest bit pleased. This is called diminishing returns: the more money you put into something, the less the effect. Most of the things we spend money on suffer from the effect of diminishing returns. There are only so many computers, shoes, hamburgers, cars, cameras, cellphones, cough drops, and {boy|girl}friends you can enjoy.

It also applies at the big scale. For example, subways are a really efficient way to move people around in big cities, and it's good to extend the subways further out into the suburbs. We could extend subways all the way to Podunktown, Nebraska, or Armpitville, Nevada, but not many people would use those subways, so we wouldn't get much value out of them. Spending enormous amounts of money on subways yields diminishing returns.

Here's another example: we can build scrubbers for coal-burning power plants that remove 99% of the sulfur dioxide and nitrous oxides. If we wanted to, we could build even better scrubbers that remove 99.5% of the pollutants – but those more powerful scrubbers would cost us a lot more money to get that extra 0.5%. And if we wanted to get 99.9% of the pollutants, the scrubbers to do that would cost a humongous amount of money. That's diminishing returns for ya.

Term.Title: Drought
Term.Text: Droughts are lengthy periods during which an insufficient amount of rain falls in a region. Droughts are exacerbated by high temperatures, because plants need more water when it's hotter. Droughts have plagued humanity for all of history, but the last ten years have seen larger, longer, and more serious droughts than any previous time. In South America, the Amazon basin has suffered from several droughts that contributed to huge forest fires. Australia has long had droughts but over the last ten years, it has experienced the most severe long-term drought in its history. The Sahel region along the southern edge of the Sahara desert in Africa has been experiencing a long-term drought for years now, and the Sahara desert is expanding southward. The drought in Texas in 2011 set records and has caused economic losses of at least $5 billion – and it's not over yet. Drought in Kenya and Somalia has triggered a famine that has killed over 100,000 people. All over the globe, droughts are hotter, drier, and more frequent.

Term.Title: Economies of Scale
Term.Text:
Suppose that you need to dig a small hole, and you know that it's the only hole you'll need to dig in your whole life. The most economical strategy would be to dig it with your bare hands, or maybe use a nearby stick or rock to dig it.

Now suppose that you are planting a small garden. You know that you'll have to dig a number of holes, so you decide to purchase a shovel. It's a small investment, but it will greatly increase the efficiency of your hole-digging.

Now suppose that you need to dig a lot of big, deep holes, say for construction. A shovel just won't do for this; you need an excavator like the one in the picture.

There's a pattern here: the bigger the job, the bigger – and more expensive – the tool you need to do the job. And the cost per pound of dug dirt falls dramatically. An excavator will cost you $100,000, while a shovel might cost you only $10. The excavator costs 10,000 times as much as the shovel. But it will dig up a lot more than 10,000 times as much dirt, so in terms of dollars per pound of dirt, the excavator is cheaper than the shovel.

This basic principle is called economies of scale: the bigger you get, the more efficient you are, and the lower the cost to get the same result.

Economies of scale are the exact opposite of diminishing returns. With economies of scale, the bigger your effort, the more efficient it is. But with diminishing returns, the bigger your purchase, the less you get for it. The difference comes in the use. When you're making things (manufacturing), you get economies of scale. When you're buying things, you get diminishing returns. An excavator is a lot more efficient than a shovel, but having a thousand shirts isn't ten times better than having a hundred shirts.

Term.Title: Electric Cars
Term.Text:
The basic design of an electric car is very simple. Instead of a gas tank, there's a battery. Instead of a gasoline engine, there's an electric motor. A gasoline engine uses hundreds of parts; an electric motor has a few dozen.

Electric motors have a huge advantage over gasoline engines: they have their highest torque at low speeds, while gasoline engines have their lowest torque at low speeds. Torque is "twisting power": the power to make the wheels turn even when there's a big load. Horsepower measures how much power an engine can deliver at its best speed; torque measures how much power it can deliver when starting to move.

This is important because the first job of any car engine is to get the car moving from a stop. An electric motor can do that directly, but gasoline engines have to be spinning pretty fast to have enough power to get the car moving. That creates a problem: if the wheels aren't turning at all and the engine is turning fast, how do you connect the engine to the wheels without a clash? We solve this problem with a clutch, a pair of disks that rub against each other. One disk connects to the engine, the other to the wheels. When you press down on the clutch pedal, you separate the two disks. As you slowly release the clutch pedal, the two disks start rubbing together lightly, and some of the fast spinning of the engine-disk starts the wheel-disk spinning slowly. As you release the clutch pedal, the two disks rub together more tightly and more of the engine's spinning is transmitted to the wheels. If you release the clutch pedal too fast, then the engine won't have enough torque to make the wheels spin, and the car lurches to a halt. The ideal technique is particuarly difficult for student drivers to learn.

Most of the power of an engine is used to get the car moving. Electric motors do this easily, but gasoline engines don't, so you need a lot of extra power from the gasoline engine to accomplish what a smaller electric motor can do. That's why electric cars don't need as much power as gasoline cars: they're more efficient at starting the car.

The greatest weakness of electric cars is their batteries. A pound of gasoline stores a lot more energy than a pound of battery; to carry enough energy to equal a tank of gasoline, you'd need more than a ton of batteries. Your electric car would be so heavy that it wouldn't go very fast.

But researchers have been developing ever more powerful batteries that can store more energy, making electric cars better. The other big advance is in materials science: researchers are coming up with lighter, stronger materials to build a car with. A lighter car doesn't need as much energy to go fast, so that makes electric cars even more practical.

Despite these advances, it is unlikely that electric cars will ever completely replace gasoline engines. Most likely, we'll see electric cars used for commuting and big diesel engines used for long-haul trucking. Between these two extremes, there will be some mixing of the two types.

Term.Title: Energy and Transportation
Term.Text:
The biggest savings are to be found in transportation. Walking gets the equivalent of about 300 mpg (miles per gallon of gasoline); bicycling is the most efficient form of transportation, attaining the equivalent of 700 mpg. Motor scooters get 80 mpg. Hybrids such as the Toyota Prius get between 40 mpg and 50 mpg. Most American cars range between 20 and 30 mpg, but Americans have a love for big cars that get lousy mileage. And the absolute record for low gas mileage must go to the Bagger 288 that is used to dig coal. It gets about 0.0007 mpg!
We burn so much energy in transportation because we spend most of the energy transporting the machinery, not the people. A typical American car weighs over 3,000 pounds, of which only 6% is the actual human cargo. In other words, 94% of the energy we use for our cars is completely wasted.
Reducing the weight of cars is the obvious solution, but that raises safety questions. Still, we can get by without most of the 2-ton dinosaurs lumbering down our roads, and we don't need four-passenger cars for one-passenger commutes. In fact, millions of people all over the world are doing just fine with very small cars.

Then there are the high-tech cars of the future: electric cars, which have actually been around for a long time, and hydrogen cars.

Term.Title: Exajoule
Term.Text:
An exajoule is a whole lotta energy. More precisely, an exajoule is 1,000,000,000,000,000,000 joules.

Great. What's a joule?

A joule is a small amount of energy. Picking a book up off the floor takes roughly one joule of energy. A large incandescent light bulb uses about 100 joules every second. Accelerating a car from 0 to 60 mph requires about half a million joules. One gallon of gasoline contains about 130 million joules.

So what does the "exa" mean? Think in terms of memory storage on your computer. One byte is, well, one byte. A kilobyte is a thousand bytes. A megabyte is a million bytes – most digital photos take a few megabytes. A gigabyte is a billion bytes – most computers have a few gigabytes of RAM. A terabyte is a trillion bytes – most computers have maybe a terabyte of hard disk storage. A petabyte is a quadrillion bytes – about as much as a thousand big hard drives can store. And an exabyte is a quintillion bytes – it would take a million big hard drives to store that much data. So an exajoule is a quintillion joules. Not as much as a gazillion joules, but that's still a lot of joules.

Oh, and why do we call this unit of energy a "joule"? It's named after James Prescott Joule, the old fart in the picture. He was an English physicist who did some research in thermodynamics. Aren't you glad that it wasn't named after Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar, who was actually a better physicist? Can you imagine how big a gigachandrasekhar would be?

Term.Title: Fracking
Term.Text:
Natural gas is trapped in rocks deep underground. It's a fossil fuel like oil and coal, coming from the same sources that generated oil and coal. Sometimes it's mixed in with oil, and so when we drill the oil, we get the natural gas as a bonus. That's how we've gotten all our natural gas in the past.

But those methods only reach a small fraction of the natural gas in the ground. There's lots more spread thinly through vast rock formations. It's not worthwhile to drill a well for it, because we only get the natural gas that's close to the well. Isn't that sad? Boo-hoo.

But wait! There's another way! Suppose we drill a well down for a ways, then drill sideways into a long horizontal layer of rock containing thinly-spread natural gas. Then we pump water down into the well and suddenly compress the water to very high pressures. The high pressure fractures the rock for some distance from the well, freeing up lots more natural gas, which then comes up to the surface. Fracturing the rock this way is called fracking

The amount of natural gas we can get by fracking is enormous: the biggest shale formation in the US, the Marcellus formation underneath Pennsylvania and West Virginia, is estimated to hold about 15 trillion gallons of gasoline worth of energy — that's more than ten times as much as all the oil used in the world each year.

There are three problems with fracking. First, it uses a lot of water: a typical well will require perhaps 400,000 gallons of water. This is not a problem in water-rich places like Pennsylvania, but in the western states, where water is scarce, this is more problematic. The water doesn't come back up, so we can't reuse it.

Another problem with fracking is the possibility that it will contaminate underground water supplies. At this time, there is no proof that such contamination happens – but that doesn't mean much, because it can take decades for the contaminated water used for fracking seeps into water wells. If, thirty years from now, Grandpa Joe's water well is ruined by fracking taking place today, who does Grandpa Joe sue? The company that did the fracking made its money and could be out of business.

The third problem with fracking is that we really don't know how much of that natural gas we can really get using fracking. Some rocks are so hard that fracking doesn't free up much natural gas; some of the natural gas is really deep. There's a big difference between what we think is down there and what we can actually get our grubby little hands on.

Fracking can also be used to improve the yield from oil wells and even revives old, low-yield water wells. Of course, they don't use nasty chemicals when fracking water wells; they use regular water, which isn't as efficient but is clean and safe.

Term.Title: Free Markets
Term.Text:
Overall, the free market is the best way to sort out how best to allocate resources (in other words, spend money) and provide them to people. For example, suppose that your neighbor likes to drive a big gas-hog SUV. That thing really burns up gasoline! We're tempted to condemn people like that for wasting energy. But wait a minute: can you really say that you only use gasoline for trips that are absolutely necessary? Have you ever taken a ride in the country just for fun? Do you take the car to go shopping not because you need to buy food, but because you just enjoy shopping? If you use gasoline for frivolous activities, how can you condemn somebody else for doing the same thing? We all do it!

You could defend yourself by saying that your activities aren't as frivolous as the next guy's — but who's to say what's really frivolous and what's not so frivolous? Do we want laws saying that driving SUVs is frivolous, but going to football games isn't? That's just not fair.

There's a better way to sort this out: the price mechanism. If gasoline costs money, then people will decide for themselves how much money they're willing to spend on those "frivolous" activities. You may decide that using gasoline to drive an SUV is frivolous, and so you wouldn't spend the money to do so. But your neighbor has different values and decides that it's worth the money. That way, you get to do what's important to you, and your neighbors get to do what's important to them. Everybody wins, right?

The system balances out nicely because, if people want more gasoline, then they'll be willing to pay a higher price for it. That higher price will motivate oil companies to drill more wells and produce more gasoline for everybody. It all fits together neatly and everybody comes out ahead – right?

Not so fast. There are a few problems with this way of thinking. The first arises from externalities: the price you pay at the pump doesn't reflect the true cost of the gasoline. For example, when we burn gasoline, we release polluting gases like NOx that damage property and inflict tiny amounts of lung damage on large numbers of people. Scientists have shown that the pollution from cars causes some people to die from asthma, emphysema, and lung cancer. But the lady driving the SUV doesn't pay for those people's medical bills, and neither do you. They get stuck with the costs of your burning gasoline. That's not fair, is it?

Here's another problem: there's only so much oil in the ground. Since there's a limited supply, selling oil is like an auction. Each person decides how much they're willing to pay for the oil and 'bids' for the oil by buying it at that price, and we divvy up the oil based on people's 'bids'. That sounds fair, doesn't it? Sure – so long as everybody has a fair chance to bid. With gas stations all over the place, it sure looks as if everybody does have a fair chance to bid, right?

But what about the people who aren't here yet? What about your children who haven't been born yet? They're not here yet, so they can't bid on the oil. All we 2013 people are bidding for the same oil that the people in 2060 will want to use. But those people aren't here, so they don't get a fair chance to make their bids. Suppose that they had agents representing them, agents who bid today on oil for use in the future. Those agents would make higher bids, which would drive up the price for us. Since those agents aren't here, we're all paying less for gasoline than we would if the free market were truly fair. Which means we're burning it up faster that we would if everything were fair.

Here's another example of how free markets don't always work well: efficient markets aren't the same as perfect markets. A perfect market is one in which there's so much competition that every seller has to keep his prices down to the absolute minimum. The opposite of a perfect market is a monopoly. If only one company is selling something that everybody wants, that company can charge exorbitant prices and people just have to pay what that company demands. Monopolies are bad for the economy and they're unfair, so we have laws against monopolies.

On the other hand, perfect markets divide everything up so that only little companies do the selling. That forces companies to stay small, but often times big companies are more efficient than little companies. Big companies can afford the huge investments required for modern technologies that allow us to tap into larger supplies of oil. A single deep-sea ocean rig can cost $4 billion; only big oil companies can afford that kind of equipment. If we had a perfect market for oil, then there wouldn't be any companies big enough to purchase deep-sea drilling rigs, and there'd be less oil for everybody.

There's no simple way to trade off the benefits of perfect markets against the benefits of efficient markets. We just have to compromise one against the other, because free markets don't always work the way we want them to.

These big companies create a new problem called moral hazard. This happens in financial markets where huge companies are so critical to the economy that they know that the government won't permit them to go bankrupt. Knowing that they won't have to pay the costs of huge mistakes, they take big risks, risks that pay off handsomely most of the time (making the bankers rich) – and when the risks fail, costing hundreds of billions of dollars, the government will bail them out. This is exactly what happened in the fall of 2008, when the American financial system nearly collapsed because of foolish risks taken by huge financial institutions like banks. The taxpayers had to bail them out to prevent even greater losses.

I'm not saying that we should give up on free markets; they're still the best overall way to deal with these problems. But we shouldn't have blind faith in free markets: like everything else, they're imperfect and in some cases they don't work well. In those cases, it's possible for one group of people to cheat another group of people out of billions of dollars.
