Term.Title: Fusion Energy
Term.Text:
For decades, the dream of fusion energy has excited scientists, because the basic fuel for fusion energy is the hydrogen in water – and the water in our oceans could provide immense amounts of power for millions of years. As far as we're concerned, fusion is an infinite source of energy. All we have to do is get it working.

That, it turns out, is not so easy. It's one thing to build an H-bomb, which uses fusion to blow things up. To control fusion reactions, however, is immensely more difficult. The basic problem is that fusion requires temperatures of millions of degrees. What kind of container can hold anything that hot?

The first idea was called a magnetic bottle. The idea is to set up magnetic fields that confine the superhot plasma. It works because plasma – the superheated stuff that the sun is made of, and which is necessary for fusion reactions – is strongly affected by magnetic fields, and so a magnetic bottle will definitely hold plasma. The catch is that it's a two-way street: not only do magnetic fields strongly affect plasma, but plasma strongly affects magnetic fields. Which means that, once you set up your magnetic bottle with plasma inside it, the movements of the plasma deform the magnetic bottle, which cause the plasma to move, which deforms the magnetic bottle even more, and so on until the magnetic bottle breaks down. Scientists spent years trying to fix this problem, and they could never get it working. The problem is so difficult that they even gave it a difficult name: magnetohydrodynamics.

The next big idea was a Russian one, called Tokamak. The basic idea is to set up a magnetic bottle shaped liked a donut. The plasma could move around in a circle inside the magnetic donut. The plan was to keep the plasma so busy running around inside the donut that it would never try to get outside the donut. They came close, but they could never get it working right.

The next big idea is really cool. We start with a tiny little droplet of fusion fuel at the top of a big hollow steel sphere. We drop it and it falls downward. The instant it reaches the precise center of the sphere, we blast it with a bunch of super high power lasers that raise its temperature up to the millions of degrees necessary to fusion to begin. All those fusion reactions generate energy. The idea is to have a steady stream of these droplets getting blasted many times per second, releasing lots of energy. The problem is that the super high power lasers require almost as much energy as the fusion reactions release. Plus there are problems keeping the equipment working for a long time when there are millions of tiny H-bomb explosions going on inside. They've been working on getting it right for 30 years now and someday – someday – they might get it working right. Don't hold your breath.

There are some even wilder ideas for fusion power, but none of them have even gotten to the experimental stage.

Term.Title: Gaia Hypothesis
Term.Text:
Symbiosis is the constructive interaction between two or more species. For example, the clownfish (Nemo was a clownfish) has a symbiotic relationship with the sea anemone. The clownfish eats little bugs that eat the anemone, and the anemone's stingers, to which the clownfish is immune, protect the clownfish from predators. Together, the two species are better off than alone.

There are plenty of similar examples of symbiosis in the biosphere. But why should the concept of symbiosis be limited to just two species acting together? Deep inside your gut, loads of different bacteria help you digest your food. If you eat bad food containing a nasty bacterium such as Escherichia coli, that bacterium will mess up the delicate balance inside your gut and your digestive system will malfunction, leading to what we call food poisoning. Not fun.

If many different species can interact in complex fashion, why can't everything interact symbiotically? That is, do all the living things on this planet interact symbiotically? Do all species work together for their mutual benefit?

Obviously many species don't help each other, they hurt each other. Mice probably don't consider cats to be their benefactors, and grass probably doesn't appreciate the attentions of cattle. But there are also lots of constructive interactions. All the plants on the planet emit oxygen; if there were too much oxygen, then eventually huge forest fires would burn all the plants. Animals convert oxygen into carbon dioxide, which the plants need for their own chemistry. Thus, plants and animals together enjoy a mutually beneficial symbiotic relationship.

The Gaia Hypothesis claims that the biosphere is symbiotic on a huge scale. This is controversial for a number of reasons. First, it's obvious that, because of predation (creatures eating other creatures), symbiosis is only partial. Of course, the oxygen-carbon dioxide relationship between plants and animals also demonstrates some degree of symbiosis. So the controversy turns over how much symbiosis exists at the planetary level.

The second portion of the controversy is due to an unfortunate misunderstanding. It's best understood by comparison with evolution theory. When we trace the evolution of a species such as our own, it's all too easy to see purposefulness in the progression. Over millions of years, hominids grew more and more intelligent; was this because somebody (Mother Nature? God? Aliens?) was directing the course of evolution? Of course not! We know that this progress was really just a long sequence of perfectly natural adaptations to changing environments. But it certainly is easy to imagine a guiding hand in the process.

In the same fashion, some people have interpreted the Gaia Hypothesis to mean that some guiding intelligence (the goddess Gaia?) guides all living things so that they cooperate with each other to keep the biosphere healthy. This is fantasy. The Gaia Hypothesis does not assume any guiding purpose; it instead posits high-level symbiosis that helps keep the biosphere healthy. The mechanisms of this symbiosis are just as unknown to us now as genetics was to Charles Darwin.

It's true that some New Age mystics misrepresent the Gaia Hypothesis as scientific proof of their worldview; the fact that they do does not discredit the Gaia Hypothesis.

Term.Title: Generation III Reactor Tech
Term.Text:
Almost all of the nuclear power plants currently in use are Generation II reactors. They were designed in the 1960s and 1970s, based on the experience gained from the first research reactors in the 1950s. Generation II reactors have racked up about 15,000 reactor-years of experience, and during that time they have amassed a fairly good safety record.

The first major accident of a Generation II reactor was at Three Mile Island in 1979, and the safety systems did their job: no significant amount of radioactivity was released and, thirty years later, there is no evidence of any harm to the public ever occurring. The accident at Chernobyl was a very serious accident, but that reactor did not conform to any of the safety standards used in the Western countries. The most serious accident at a Generation II reactor was the Fukushima accident. We still don't have solid data, but the evidence so far is that the total amount of radioactivity released was significant enough to cause perhaps a few hundred cases of cancer in the Japanese population.

Engineers have used the experience of the last 40 years to design a new generation of reactors. This generation, called Generation III is not radically different from the previous generation. The reactors are still light water reactors using water to transport heat from a reactor to generate heat to drive a turbine. The differences lie in a large number of refinements in the entire system. For example, engineers have developed advanced computer sensor systems that spot trouble sooner and give operators a clearer idea of conditions inside the reactor. Every aspect of the safety systems has been beefed up, from larger, thicker concrete foundations to contain melted fuel, to larger pumps for getting more water into the reactor, to more precise positioning of the control rods, to better protection against false alarms, which tend to make the operators less responsive to real accidents.

Basically, the difference between Generation III and Generation II is analogous to the difference between the engine in a modern car and the engine in a Volkswagen Beetle. It's still the same basic design, but there's a lot more stuff in there to provide higher efficiency and greater safety.

Term.Title: Generation IV Reactor Tech
Term.Text:
This is the snazzy, high-tech version of nuclear power. It includes a number of technologies, all of which promise big advances over current nuclear power technology. Here are a few of the many ideas under development:

Fast neutrons: The neutrons that are created in nuclear reactions move very fast, so fast that they tend to zoom right by uranium nuclei before they can react with it. All commercial power plants therefore rely on moderators to slow down the neutrons coming out of the nuclear reactions. These slower neutrons are more efficient at triggering nuclear reactions. However, they tend to ignore the other radioactive nasty stuff in the fuel, and so the nuclear waste coming out of commercial power reactors is nasty. Fast neutrons aren't as good at triggering uranium reactions, but they're very good at clobbering all the nasty stuff that makes up nuclear waste. Therefore, if we eliminate the moderator and use fast neutrons instead of slow neutrons, the radioactive waste we end up with is much cleaner. In addition, fast neutrons are necessary for breeder reactors. Therefore, many Generation IV reactor designs use fast neutrons.

As always, there's a catch. We must compensate for the fact that the fast neutrons aren't as efficient at triggering uranium nuclear reactions. The best way to do this is to concentrate the fuel more densely. However, when the nuclear fuel is concentrated more densely, the reactor is trickier to operate and could – theoretically – blow up like a nuclear bomb if things went horribly wrong.

Sodium coolant: Sodium in its pure form is a metal that melts at low temperatures. It has higher heat capacity than water and is therefore much better at soaking up lots of heat, so it makes a wonderful coolant. Even better, sodium doesn't slow down neutrons the way that water does, so it's good for reactors with fast neutrons. There's just one catch: sodium burns fiercely when exposed to water. Even the water vapor in air is sufficient to cause a small fire. Should a sodium-cooled reactor ever suffer a leak or broken pipe, we'll have a fire inside the power plant. That's not good. Of course, sodium-cooled systems are so efficient that they operate at the same pressure your house plumbing works at, so there's less chance of a leak than there is with high-pressure water systems in conventional reactors.

Gas coolants: There are a number of designs that use gases to cool the reactor, helium being the most common gas. The advantage of helium is that it is inert: it doesn't pick up any loose radioactivity like water can, and it can't react with anything, so it there wouldn't be any fires. The catch with gases is that they don't hold a lot of heat; to carry away enough heat, they have to be kept at very high pressures, which means that the pipes and under high stress. That's not good.

Thorium fuel cycle:It's possible to use thorium as a fuel if we use it in a breeder reactor. That's good on two counts: first, there's lots of thorium to dig up for fuel, and second, the reactions involving thorium never produce anything that could be used for a nuclear bomb.

All in all, Generation IV designs are still in the research phase, not the development phase. The earliest date at which we might see such designs in working power plants is 2030 – and that's optimistic.

Term.Title: Geoengineering
Term.Text:
Let's suppose that the pipe carrying sewage from your toilets broke and began leaking raw sewage into the crawl space under your house. After a week or two, your house would start to smell pretty bad. Now, some people in such circumstances would call a plumber and have it fixed. But let's suppose that you're too cheap to call a plumber, so you come up with a better solution: you buy a crate of air freshener and every day spray the whole house with lots of air freshener. Problem solved, right?

A lot of people wouldn't call that much of a solution; other people might call it geoengineering

.

There are lots of wild schemes for geoengineering approaches to climate change, but two proposals might have some merit. The first is called stratospheric sulfate injection (dumping a million tons of sulfate compounds into the stratosphere every year), and the second is called ocean fertilization.

Just to show that scientists don't lack imagination, here are some of the other ideas that have been bandied about:

Space sunshades: Let's put huge umbrellas into orbit; they'd block some of the sunlight and help cool the earth!

Ocean foam: All we need to do is mix a few million tons of detergent into the ocean, and all that foam on the ocean's surface would reflect sunlight, helping cool the earth!

Biochar: Start with one ton of organic residues: dead plants, dead trees, dead squirrels – anything that was once alive. Chop it into fine pieces. Carefully heat it in a huge closed pot with no oxygen inside. It will release natural gas that you can capture and use as fuel. When fully cooked, you get a yukky black mess called biochar which is just loaded with carbon. Bury that stuff, and you've removed a lot of carbon from the environment. Repeat several billion times each year and you will have cleaned up some of the carbon dioxide that we emit during that time!

Ocean water inversion: Build a big pipe about 30 feet across and four miles long. Drop it vertically into the ocean so that the bottom rests on the ocean floor and the top is just below the surface. Attach some huge water pumps that pump water from the bottom of the ocean to the surface. That bottom water is very cold and will cool the surface of the ocean. Set up a few thousand more of these pipes and you've made a kind of "ocean air conditioner" to cool the planet! (Batteries not included).

As you can see, we're not short of ideas for dealing with climate change. What we're short of is good ideas for dealing with climate change.

Term.Title: Glaciers
Term.Text: Glaciers are probably the most sensitive indicator of climate change; people noticed that glaciers were shrinking well before we figured out that it was because of climate change. The photograph shows the South Cascade glacier in Washington state; you can see that in just 24 years it has already shrunk quite a bit. Glaciers all over the world are shrinking fast: in the Andes of South America, Mt. Kilimanjaro in Africa, Tajikistan, the Himalayas, Canada, Alaska, Siberia, Montana, New Zealand, Greenland – in fact, glaciers everywhere are shrinking. The biggest loss is in the biggest glacier in the world, called Ilulissat in northwest Greenland. This single glacier puts more ice into the sea than all of the other glaciers of the world combined. It is likely that the iceberg that sank the Titanic came from Ilulissat. In the last 12 years, this glacier has shortened by 12 miles and it is continuing to shorten. At least future Titanics will be safer.

Term.Title: Greenhouse Effect
Term.Text:
Let's put the pieces together now: the earth achieves thermodynamic equilibrium by emitting infrared light into space exactly equal to the amount of heat energy in the sunlight coming into the earth. That infrared light consists of photons that travel through the air. Now we add another tidbit: carbon dioxide molecules absorb infrared photons using the processes described here. So let's imagine an infrared photon emitted from the warm surface of the earth. It flies upward towards space. But lo! It bumps into a carbon dioxide molecule that absorbs it, then re-emits it a split second later. The original photon was heading upwards towards space, but the new photon could be going in any direction. If you think about it, you'll realize that half of the directions are upwards and half are downwards. That means that, if a thousand original photons heading upward towards space collide with a thousand carbon dioxide molecules, then 500 of the newly-emitted photons will end up heading upward and the other 500 newly-emitted photons will end up heading downward – back to the earth.

Thus, the carbon dioxide acts like an insulating blanket: it reflects some of the heat-carrying infrared photons right back to the earth, so the earth doesn't cool off as quickly. If the earth can't cool off as efficiently, it will retain more heat, which will cause temperatures to rise. This is the greenhouse effect.

Now there's good news and there's bad news. The good news is that there aren't that many carbon dioxide molecules in the atmosphere, so not many infrared photons get intercepted by carbon dioxide. The bad news is that, by pumping billions of tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, we're increasing the number of carbon dioxide molecules in the air. In the last 50 years we have increased the amount of carbon dioxide in the air by 22%, and the amount of carbon dioxide that we add each year is increasing.

But it gets even worse! We haven't talked about the effects of the ocean's heat capacity!

Term.Title: Greenhouse Gases
Term.Text:
Carbon dioxide isn't the only greenhouse gas; there are actually a bunch of gases that contribute to the greenhouse effect. But only two of these gases are important enough to worry about: water vapor and methane.

Yep, plain old water vapor is a greenhouse gas. For example, have you ever been in a hot, humid place? Humidity is just the amount of water vapor in the air. Since water vapor is a powerful greenhouse gas, and there's so much of it in the air, it really holds the heat on the surface, and so you don't get a lot of cooling during the night.

Have you ever spent the night in the desert? If so, you'll know that it gets cold as soon as the sun goes down. That's because there's very little water vapor in the air (deserts are dry, remember?). Without any water vapor, there's nothing to hold back the infrared radiation and the earth cools rapidly.

Another example comes when you have a winter storm followed by a clearing. Cold air doesn't hold much water vapor, so the atmosphere has little water vapor to hold back the infrared light from the earth, and when night falls, temperatures plummet. When it's cloudy, you don't feel much temperature difference between day and night, but when it's cold and clear, you can get real cold real fast when the sun goes down.

Methane is another greenhouse gas. Molecule for molecule, methane is 20 times more powerful in intercepting infrared light than carbon dioxide. The good news is that methane doesn't last long in the atmosphere: the average methane molecule in the air breaks down after ten years or so. The bad news is that it breaks down into carbon dioxide. Gotcha!

Where does methane come from? Lots of places. One source is cow burps and farts. Cows make a lot of methane while they're digesting grass, and that methane always comes out in the end – one end or the other.

Another source of methane is natural gas – in fact, natural gas IS methane. Now, we don't like to waste natural gas, but the fact is that a lot of it leaks out of all the pipes and doodads that we use with natural gas. A lot of it also leaks out during the process of getting it out of the ground. The more natural gas we use, the more leaks into the atmosphere where it only adds to the greenhouse effect. We just can't win for losing, can we?

Term.Title: Heat Capacity
Term.Text:
Here's a simple experiment that you don't really need to do, because you've already done it plenty of times. Heat up a pot of water on the stove almost to boiling. Let it sit for an hour, then stick your finger in the water to see how hot it is. Even after an hour, it's still pretty hot, isn't it? If you heated up a fork or spoon, it would cool off pretty quickly. How is that water can stay hot so long?

The answer has to do with something called heat capacity: the amount of heat that something can store. To understand heat capacity, let's think about sponges. First, imagine a really good sponge. You can pour water all over it, and it just soaks up all that water. Compare that with a really lousy sponge: it can't hold as much water. So we can say that sponges have a "water capacity": the amount of water that a sponge can hold.

Heat capacity is the same thing, only for heat, not water. You "pour heat" into a pan of water and the water soaks up the heat and gets hot slowly. Metal, on the other hand, has low heat capacity, so if you "pour heat" into metal, it heats up quickly. So, to summarize, water can hold a lot of heat without getting much hotter. In the picture we symbolize this with two imaginary test tubes; one has low heat capacity and the other has high heat capacity. If we "pour" the same amount of heat into both test tubes, the temperature in the one with low heat capacity rises more quickly than the temperature in the one with high heat capacity.

Throw in the fact that the oceans have a LOT of water, and you can see that the earth has, as a whole, a lot of heat capacity. In fact, it has so much heat capacity that, if the sun just died tomorrow and stopped shining, the earth would start to cool – but there's so much heat stored in the oceans that it would take four months for the oceans to freeze!

Now let's take the idea of heat capacity and use it with the greenhouse effect in mind. You may recall that I told you that we humans have increased the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere by 22%. Let's suppose that this extra carbon dioxide reduces the amount of heat (infrared radation) leaving the earth by just one-tenth of 1%. So, instead of 200 petawatts of heat leaving the earth, we have only 199.8 petawatts leaving the earth. The difference between the solar input (200 petawatts) and the infrared output (199.8 petawatts) is just 0.2 petawatts. All that heat goes to heating up the earth. Now, if you had a microwave oven with 0.2 petawatts of power, it would heat a gallon of water from ice-cold to boiling in ten billionths of a second. 0.2 petawatts is a lot of power! But the oceans have a lot of heat capacity, and those 0.2 petawatts of power would take 15 years to increase the temperature of the oceans by just 1ºF.

Think about that. If we increase the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere to increase the temperature by just 1ºF, it would take 15 years before the effect showed up, because the oceans act like a huge shock absorber for heat. We don't feel the shock until 15 years after we've put the carbon dioxide in the air. Which means that things may look OK right now, but if there are going to be any bad consequences for our climate decisions today, we won't experience those repercussions for at least 15 years. It's like driving a truck so big and heavy that it can't slow down very fast. If you see that there's an obstacle in the road ahead and you hit the brakes, the truck slows down so slowly that you'll crash unless you looked very far ahead. That's what we have to do with climate change: look very far ahead.

Term.Title: Heat Pump
Term.Text:
A heat pump is a machine that moves heat from one place to another. Air conditioners are heat pumps; so are refrigerators and deep freezers. Some houses use heat pumps for both heating and cooling.

The basic operation of a heat pump is fairly simple. We start with the electrical pump at the top center of the diagram. This pump compresses a special gas that's perfect for this job. Now, when you compress a gas, its temperature rises. If you've ever pumped up a bicycle tire, you may have noticed that the nozzel of the pump is hot when you're done. That's because the pump was compressing all the air that went into the tire.

So the hot, compressed gas flows into a heat exchanger (in red) which is just a bunch of copper tubes. A fan blows air over the copper tubes, which cools the copper tubes, cooling the compressed gas. Now the compressed gas moves on to an expansion valve (bottom center), which permits the gas to expand. When you let a gas expand, it cools. Have you ever sprayed yourself with deoderant and felt how cold it is? The spray is cold because the gas in the spray can is expanding. In the same way, the expanding gas cools as it expands. But it started off cooler than it was when it was compressed (because the fan was cooling it). So when it cools, it gets really cold. The cold gas then moves through the cooling tubes inside your refrigerator, cooling the food. From there it goes back to the compressor pump and the whole cycle starts all over.

There are a number of tricks you can use to increase the efficiency of a heat pump, such as using a gas the condenses into a liquid when it is cooled and evaporates back into a gas when it is warmed. All these tricks together increase the overall efficiency of a heat pump to as much as 40%. But it still takes energy: electricity is needed to run the compressor motor.

Term.Title: Heat Waves
Term.Text:
You know what a heat wave is; you've probably experienced several in the last few years. In fact, since the year 2000, heat waves have been striking frequently and setting new records all over the world. The United States experienced heat waves in August 2001; April 2002; July and August 2006; June 2008; July 2010; July and August, 2011. The rest of the world has also experienced a series of devastating heat waves during the same period. Not only are heat waves becoming more frequent, they are lasting longer. In times past, a heat wave might last a few days to a week; nowadays, heat waves can drag on for weeks.

Record-setting temperatures are one way to measure just how serious heat waves can be. In June 2011, 2706 weather stations in the US recorded record high daily temperatures; only 251 set record low daily temperatures. Until 1980, there were just as many high temperature records being set as low temperature records. That makes sense, after all; you expect that, from year to year, you'd have just as many record-setting hot days as record-setting cold days. But since 1980, that hasn't been happening. Over the last ten years, there have been an average of twice as many record high temperatures as record low temperatures – and it's getting worse every year.

Heat waves kill. Lots of people don't know that they have to drink more water during a heat wave. Lots of old and sick people with weakened constitutions suffer greatly because their bodies can't handle all that extra heat; many die. Heat waves used to kill an average of 400 people every year just in the United States, but that number has been climbing and was over 7000 in 2011. The heat wave in Europe in 2003 killed 35,000 people.

Heat waves are also expensive. People use a lot more electricity during a heat wave to run their air conditioners. The power company is legally required to have enough power to meet that extra demand for electricity, so it must keep special generators ready to go every day. These are called "peak power plants" and are usually gas turbines. The problem is, they're not used except when it's really hot. That means that these power plants sit idle 90% of the time. The power company still has to pay for them, even though they don't run often. And that extra cost is passed on to you, the customer – which means that you're paying for generators that don't run very often. Most of the electricy you use is cheap to produce – maybe 9¢ per kilowatt-hour. But you probably pay about 12¢ per kilowatt hour. Why the extra charge? Because you have to pay for all the other stuff required to get the power to you: electricity lines, transformers, and all that stuff. Included in those costs is the cost of the power plants that sit idle, waiting for peak demand. Thus, high temperature records cost you money.

Term.Title: High Voltage Direct Current
Term.Text:
If you read the section on transmission losses, you already know that shipping electricity long distances leads to loss of electricity, and that the best solution to this problem is to go to higher voltages. The problem is, we're talking about, like, half a million volts. Have you ever touched a wire with half a million volts? If you have, then you're dead, and I don't know why you'd be reading this stupid story. Voltages that high can be really tricky to handle safely.

You know how a spark of static electricity can jump a tiny distance from your finger to something else? Well, a half a million volts can jump across 6 inches of empty air! So building big equipment to handle that kind of voltage is pretty tricky, and as you get closer to a million volts, the problems just become too much; we can't build power lines able to handle a million volts...

unless we use direct current. Electrical power systems use alternating current (AC), a kind of current that goes back and forth 60 times every second. Direct current (DC) just goes in one direction. Now, at the basic level, the only difference is that AC goes back and forth, like a piston going up and down in an engine, while DC always pushes in one direction, like gravity (well, at least the gravity where I live. Do you live in a place where gravity pushes and pulls alternately? If so, life must be pretty jiggly there.).

Anyway, while the difference between the two kinds of current is simple theoretically, it gets to be pretty complicated when you're talking about building circuits for handling a million volts. To make a long story short, you can't do it with AC, but you can do it with DC.

This does require some special new technology to work, but there are already a number of High Voltage Direct Current (HVDC) transmission lines around the country. If we built more of these lines, then we could ship electricity much greater distances without serious loss. The whole country could be tied together in one big grid, enjoying the advantages that arise from pooling all our resources into a single grid.

The USA has been slow to pick up on HVDC; out of 100 HVDC projects around the world, only 20 are in the US, and many of those are rather puny. The bigtime stuff is being done in Europe; most American HVDC lines use equipment manufactured in Germany.

There's an even better way to transmit large amounts of electricity: superconducting wire. If you get wire really, really cold – much colder than the heart of the meanest, nastiest penguin in Antarctica – then it suddenly changes and can conduct huge amounts of electricity without warming up at all. So if we built refrigerated transmission lines, then we could transmit all the power we wanted all over the continent without any power loss at all!

The problem is, we're not talking about regular everyday refrigerators. The refrigerators we're talking about compare to the fridge in your kitchen the way that a jet airplane compares to a tricycle. Yep, they cost a lot more. So we can't use superconducting wires yet.

But! Researchers are working hard to come up with special kinds of wires that don't need to be so cold. Every year they do a little better, and someday, they might get them good enough to allow us to build superconducting transmission lines. But don't hold your breath: it won't be anytime soon.

Term.Title: How Accurate Is This Game
Term.Text:
You're probably wondering just how reliable the results of this game are. The short answer is that it's not very accurate at all. The problems that civilization faces with energy, pollution, and climate change are enormously complicated. Even a team of the best scientists and economists wouldn't be able to produce a truly reliable simulation. So how can you trust the work of a yokel wearing a big blue hat?

My answer is that this is not meant to be perfectly accurate, it is meant to teach you the first things about the problems we face with energy, pollution, and climate change. After all, in your first science class, did they start off by teaching you quantum electrodynamics? You have to start simple, and this game is a simple introduction to the subject.

"Simple?!?!?" you snort. "This game is horribly complicated!" Well, yes, that's true: it is too complicated. It's very difficult to master. I had to make tons of agonizing decisions in which I had to choose between making it easier to understand and making it more accurate. I hope I hit the right balance.

The problem is made worse by the lack of solid data on all the different factors I explored. For example, you'd think that we have lots of good data on exactly how much oil is left in the ground. We don't. I researched this topic extensively, and came up with all sorts of contradictory evidence. I needed to come up with a formula for how much more oil we could get if the price of oil increased. That data really doesn't exist, so I had to make up a formula. I can't prove that my formula is right; all I can say is that I put a lot of research into it and came up with the best I could estimate.

Then there's the problem of political bias. People disagree on all sorts of important issues. Just how dangerous are nuclear power plants? How much coal is there? How high will temperatures rise if we put a certain amount of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere? There is no agreement on any of these issues. Once again, I did a lot of research and came up with the best numbers I could estimate. I tried hard to be fair to all sides, but I can't guarantee that my numbers are the best.

I'm proud of the final result. I put a lot of work into the research, into reading lots of different opinions, and on coming up with the best balance between accuracy and simplicity that I could figure out. I know it's not perfect, but I also know that it will help people understand our problems better. I hope you agree after you've played it.

Term.Title: Hybrids
Term.Text:
A hybrid car uses both a gasoline engine and an electric motor to run. There are two advantages to using two completely different kinds of engine

The first advantage has to do with the difference between power and torque. Power is how much energy an engine can deliver at its peak power level. Torque is how much force the engine can deliver to the wheels. The trick here is that a gasoline engine delivers its highest power only at high RPMs.

Suppose that you're waiting at a traffic light and it goes green, so you hit the gas. Your poor little gasoline engine might have 100 horsepower at full speed, but at starting speed like this, it can barely muster 20 horsepower. Sure, its gutsy at high RPMs, but at low RPMs, it's a weakling. That's why cars use transmissions with gears. If the engine were just hooked straight to the axle, then when you were getting started, the engine would be running so slowly that it would simply die.

So we use gear systems. In first gear, the engine gets to turn many revolutions for each revolution of the axle. That way, the engine can run fast (and so get lots of power) even though the car is going slowly. As the car gains speed, the engine starts going too fast, so you go into second gear, which permits the engine to run more slowly at a given speed. This goes all the way up to fourth or fifth gear, where the engine is turning at its optimal speed when you're on the freeway.

Electric motors have the opposite ability: they have maximum torque when they're just starting. So even a small electric motor can outperform a larger gasoline engine when it comes to starting from a stop. By combining a gasoline engine with an electric motor, we can use the electric motor for fast initial acceleration, and the gasoline engine for cruising speed. This is more energy-efficient because nowadays we use oversized engines to provide acceptable torque for starting from a stop; by using an electric motor instead, we can use a smaller, more efficient gasoline engine for full speed.

The second advantage of a hybrid is its ability to store and re-use energy. Stop for a moment and think about driving a car in terms of energy rather than speed. You're waiting at a traffic light and it goes green. You hit the gas and the engine starts adding energy to your car, causing it to go faster. Every second, the engine puts more energy into the car, so it goes faster and faster. When you reach cruising speed, you back off on the gas pedal because now you only need enough energy from the engine to make up for the energy lost to friction.

But when it comes time to stop the car, you have to get rid of all that energy that you built up. So you hit the brakes. The brakes convert your moving energy into heat. That's all they do: convert one form of energy into another form. Since your car has a LOT of energy when its going fast, the brakes have to convert a lot of energy into heat, and they get pretty hot. But they're air-cooled, so they usually stay cool enough to work fine. But if for some reason you were to try to get them to convert too much energy into heat, they'd overheat and stop working. You could do this by loading your car full of lead and then driving down a long steep hill, using the brakes at full speed. That's just too much energy for most brakes to handle.

Here's where the hybrid does its job. Every electric motor is ALSO an electric generator. If you put electricity into it, it turns. If you force it to turn, then electricity comes out of it. So what if you used electricity to get the car moving, and then, when you want to slow down, reverse the process: use the motor-generator to slow down the car by converting its moving energy back into electricity. If you could do this with perfect efficiency, you'd never need to recharge your battery!

Unfortunately, it never gets anywhere near close to perfect efficiency; instead, it operates with net efficiency of only 30% to 40%. But suppose that you're driving in slow traffic, stopping and starting and stopping again. With that kind of traffic, every time you hit the brakes, you're just throwing away energy as heat. But if you're in a hybrid car, nearly 40% of that energy is reclaimed by the generator. That isn't a lot of energy by itself, but if you're doing a lot of starts and stops, the savings add up.

That's why hyrids get such good mileage. A hybrid with the same performance as a regular gasoline-powered car will get around 50% better gas mileage, depending upon how it's driven.

And if you're wondering why there's a picture of a locomotive, it's because most locomotives are diesel-electric hybrids, only they don't have batteries. The diesel engine makes the electricity that the electric motor uses to move the train. In other words, diesel-electric locomotives rely solely on electricity to move. And you thought that electric vehicles are wimps!

Term.Title: Hydrogen Cars
Term.Text:
There's a lot of excitement about hydrogen cars. These are cars powered by fuel cells that combine hydrogen with oxygen to make electrical power. What's really neat about these is that their emissions consist of water – that's all! No sulfur dioxide, no NOx, no particulates, not even carbon dioxide. Just clean, pure water. Sounds neat, doesn't it?

If you haven't already wondered "What's the catch?" then you get ninety lashes with a wet noodle for missing the first law of good environmental understanding. The catch is "Where do you get the hydrogen?" The answer is: "They have to make it from electricity from regular power plants." So, if your electricity comes from coal-burning power plants (and 45% of American electricity comes from such plants), then you're really burning coal to power your car. And coal is a very dirty form of energy.

In other words, hydrogen is not an energy source, it's an energy storage form. First you use electrical energy to hydrolize water: separate it into hydrogen and oxygen. You then release the oxygen and store the hydrogen in big pressurized tanks. Trucks or pipelines then carry the hydrogen to the gas stations, where you pump it into your car. And your car combines the hydrogen back with oxygen from the air to make water. In other words, we start with water, and we end up with water.

Thus, hydrogen cars do nothing to solve our energy problems. They do, however, replace pollution from cars with pollution from coal-burning power plants.

Term.Title: Hyperbolic Cooling Towers
Term.Text:
These babies are genuinely frigorific technology! (frigorific means "cooling down"). But they're also cool because they're so elegantly simple. We just take warm water that we want to cool and spray it downwards from a height of about 15 feet. Because the spray water is warm, a lot of it evaporates, and the warm air carrying the water vapor rises. It has to rise all the way to the top of the tower before it can get out. Here's the catch: the tower is so high that the atmospheric pressure up there is lower than it is at the bottom of the tower. When you lower the air pressure, it can't hold as much water vapor, so the water vapor must condense into a fog of tiny water droplets – which is exactly the same thing that a cloud is. Now, because the water vapor is condensing, it contracts in volume to 1/1700th of its original volume (just like inside the condenser inside the power plant). Because it shrinks in volume, it lowers the pressure even more, which sucks air up from inside the tower. The only way for more air to enter the tower is through the openings at the base of the tower.

So a hyperbolic cooling tower is really a huge air pump with no moving parts! It sucks in air at the base, passing it through a shower of warm water where it picks up a lot of water vapor. The air rises to the top of the tower and dumps its water into an artificial cloud. So it's not only a huge air pump, it's also a cloud factory!

The catch is that it only works if it's big enough. You can't have dinky hyperbolic cooling towers. Most of these towers are at least 450 feet high. If you make them too small, then the pressure and temperature differences between the top and the bottom are not great enough to insure good air flow.

Term.Title: Insulation
Term.Text:
Every home needs good insulation in the walls and the roof. If your home was built in the last thirty years, it probably has good insulation, but no matter what, you should find out how good the insulation in your house is. The most common type of insulation is batting, a blanket of insulation with a metal foil on one side. If your house does not have much insulation, it's easy to buy some and lay it down in the attic. If the walls of your house aren't insulated, you can't just tear them out and install insulation batting. Instead, it might be possible to use injectible insulation. A contractor drills small holes in the exterior wall and pumps a special fluid into the gap. As the fluid dries, it expands into a solid foam that has good insulating properties.

Term.Title: Light
Term.Text:
The starting point in understanding climate change is light. There are two simple points to understand: 1) that light is composed of particles called photons, and 2) that each photon has a color.

1. Photons are the basic "atoms" of light. A beam of light is really just a flood of photons. Photons always travel at the same speed, and you'll NEVER guess the scientific term for that speed. Go ahead, give it a try. I'll wait.

OK, have you made your best guess? Here's the answer: the scientific name for the speed of light is "the speed of light". Isn't that amazing! It's roughly 186,000 miles per second. Photons are teensy-weensy; a beam of sunlight coming in your window will have about 2,000,000,000,000,000,000,001 photons. (The extra photon is for good luck.) Because they are particles, photons can hit atoms or molecules.

2. Every photon has a color. There are red photons, green photons, blue photons, and yellow photons, and all the colors in between, as shown in the picture. But there are also colors that are invisible to us. For example, a photon can be redder than red, so red that we call it infrared. Our eyes can't see infrared photons. In fact, our eyes can see only a tiny percentage of all the photons out there. Beyond infrared, there are microwave photons, then radio wave photons. On the other side, where photons are more violet than violet, they are called ultraviolet. Beyond ultraviolet there are X-rays and beyond X-rays are gamma rays.

One other small detail that will come up later: as you can see from the picture, different colors have different frequencies and different wavelengths. For example, pure green light has a frequency of about 600 teraHerz (that's 600,000,000,000,000 vibrations per second) and a wavelength of about half a micrometer (that's 0.0000005 meters).

Now that you've got the basics under your belt, you're ready for a new concept: thermal radiation.

Term.Title: Lighting
Term.Text:
You can also reduce energy waste by replacing your incandescent light bulbs with compact flourescent light bulbs or with the new high-tech LED lights.

LED lights get between 100 and 150 lumens of light per watt of power. Flourescent lights come in around 100 lumens per watt, and incandescent lights manage a crummy 20 lumens per watt.

That's why Congress passed a bill requiring higher efficiencies in light sources. This will have the effect of phasing out interstate sales of incandescent lights over the next ten years.

Right now, LED lights cost much more than incandescent lights, but let's calculate whether they really save money. We'll compare a 60-watt incandescent light bulb with an LED that produces the same amount of light. The incandescent bulb costs about $1, while the LED costs about $40. The LED lasts about 30 times longer than the bulb, so to compare properly, we need to compare the cost of 30 incandescent bulbs with one LED. Thus, so far the incadescent technology has cost you $30 while the LED technology has cost $40 – the incandescent is ahead by $10!

But wait – there's more! One incandescent bulb will burn for about 1,000 hours before burning out, so thirty bulbs will burn for 30,000 hours At a typical price for electricity of $0.10 per kilowatt-hour, that will cost you $180 in electricity. The LED, however, will cost you only about $30 for electricity. Thus, the total cost of using incandescent light bulbs in that 60-watt socket will be about $210, while the equivalent LED will cost you about $70 – one-third the cost of the incandescent bulbs!

Some people are angry that Congress passed a law phasing out incandescent light bulbs. They say that they want the freedom to buy whatever kind of light they want. I suppose you could call this "the freedom to do really stupid things". What they forget is the fact that, by wasting electricity, they drive up the price for everybody else.

Term.Title: Limits to Growth
Term.Text:
Why can't we grow solar, wind, and other renewable energy forms as quickly as we'd like? After all, computers, mobile phones, and the Internet have all grown rapidly; why can't we do the same with solar cells?

Consider, for example, the growth of personal computers. Over the 30 years from 1980 to 2010, sales grew by an average of about 30% per year. Mobile phone subscriptions increased even faster over the last 15 years, by almost 50% per year. But these are the extreme figures, and they can be attributed to the fact that in each case the technology improved dramatically even as the price was tumbling down. Let's take some more typical cases that are more pertinent. Worldwide electricity use has increased by an average of 4% per year over the last 30 years; worldwide energy use has increased by only 2% per year over the last 40 years.

There are, of course, many factors that affect the growth rate of an industry: some factors push it up, some factors push it down. But the point I want to make here is that there are factors that can put a ceiling on growth, factors that have nothing to do with technology.

Suppose that you design a fabulous piece of software that becomes very popular, so that millions of people want it. Selling your software over the Internet is totally automated: you can go from zero sales to a billion bucks overnight. But if you want to sell, say, a videogame in a box, then it takes more time to print all the boxes, make all the CDs, ship them in trucks all over the country, and so forth, so your growth has to be slower.

Suppose, however, that you want to make solar cells. You need to build a huge (expensive) factory to build them. Once you've got them built, you can't just stick 'em in WalMart and let them sell – no, you need people to install them, whether it's in the home or in big solar parks.

But you'll need even more. You need experienced executives who know all the ins and outs of the solar cell business, so you don't lose your shirt. You need thousands of managers who know how to organize and lead a team of people who carry out the installations safely. You need inspectors to guarantee the quality of the product and the installation. And there will certainly be lots of government inspectors to make sure that you're not posing a threat to other people. Where are experienced government inspectors going to come from?

A big industry spending billions of dollars requires thousands and thousands of people to do all the tasks required to do it safely, quickly, efficiently, and at the lowest cost. You can't just hire kids out of high school to do this work; even college graduates are useless until they've learned the ropes. And when an industry is just getting started, like the solar cell industry, who knows the ropes?

I remember, back in the early days of computer games at Atari, nobody knew what they were doing, because nobody had ever done it before. The executives were totally clueless – they'd never even played a game. Those of us who were making games just made things up as we went along. We made all kinds of stupid mistakes, because we were just learning how to make games that were fun. If a games company nowadays were run as shoddily as Atari (and all the other early companies) was run, they'd go broke before they ever got any games done. Nowadays we have thousands of people with years of experience who know how to run a big games operation. But it took 30 years to get from there to here.

It takes years to build up the army of experienced people necessary to run an industry. You can send software over the Internet in seconds; you can stamp out computer chips in months; but you need years to build up a big community of people who can make an industry go.

That's one reason why solar energy will never grow as fast as we want it to. In this game, all the energy industries are limited to a maximum growth rate of 20% per year.

Term.Title: Measuring Thermal Performance
Term.Text:
Here's how you can measure how good the insulation is in your house. It's a simple test and doesn't give accurate results, but it will give you a rough idea of the overall thermal performance of your house.

You'll need at least one thermometer, but two are better. You'll also need a cold evening. This experiment works only if you have forced-air central heating (in other words, a furnace or heat pump somewhere that heats air and blows it out of registers on the floor, or sometimes the walls, all over the house.)

First determine the heat output of your heater. On the outside of the heater there should be a little notice describing the heater and somewhere the magic words "(number) BTU/hr". The (number) will tell you how many BTU's (never mind what a BTU is, we don't need it) of heat that your heater pumps into the house every hour.

Now select a nice cold night when you will be slaving away at hours of homework just like you do every night. A cloudy night will give better results than a clear night. Select one of the heat registers; you can use any register in the house, but the one where you do all that onerous homework will be best. Tie onto one of the bars on the heat register something easy to see and light in weight – maybe just a bit of paper on a string. If you do it correctly it will flutter when the hot air is coming out and lay flat when it's not.

Now place your thermometer someplace in that room where it's not near any heat registers or light bulbs; you want to get a fair measure of the actual temperature in the house.

Lastly, take a piece of paper and draw two columns on it: the first marked marked "On" and the second labeled "Off". Write down the time that you start collecting data.

Set an alarm to go off every ten minutes – you can use a kitchen cooking timer or your cell phone or computer. (If you want even more accurate data, set the timer for five minutes.) Whenever the alarm goes off, look at the heat register: is the little flag fluttering? If it is, make a check mark in "On" column on a piece of paper; if it's not, make a check mark in the "Off" column.

Halfway through the experiment, write down the temperature on your thermometer and then take it outside and put it in a safe place at least three feet away from the house. Leave it there so it can measure the outside temperature.

Continue the experiment for at least two hours; the longer it runs, the more accurate the data you'll get. When it's time to quit, go outside and read the temperature on the thermometer, then come inside and write that down on your data sheet, along with the time you stopped taking data.

Analysis Whenever you have an hour or so to analyze the data, sit down with the data sheet. Count how many times the heater was on and how many times it was off. Calculate the fraction of the time that the heater was on – it's the number of times it was on divided by the total number of measurements you took. For example, suppose that I counted it as "On" 9 times and counted it as "Off" 6 times, then I get the fraction 9/15 or 0.60 as my answer.

Now multiply that fraction by the number of BTU's per hour on your heater. That tells you how many BTUs your heater generated during the experiment. In my example, if the heater is 100,000 BTU/hr, then the heater generated 60,000 BTU/hr, on average. That's how much heat escaped from your house every hour. Think about it: if your heater had to put 60,000 BTUs into your house every hour just to maintain the temperature, then 60,000 BTUs must have been leaking out of your house every hour. If you're confused by this, try reading about thermal equilibrium.

The answer you get is the number of BTU's per hour that were leaking out of your house. But we still have to take into consideration the fact that more heat escapes on really cold nights than on normally cold nights.

To do that, you first subtract the temperature outside from the temperature inside. So in our example, if the outside temperature was 48ºF, and the inside temperature was 68ºF, you'll get a temperature difference of 20ºF. Divide the number of BTUs per hour by the temperature difference. In our example, I divide 60,000 BTUs per hour by 20ºF to get an answer of 3,000 BTUs per hour per ºF.

But we STILL haven't taken everything into account. We must also consider the fact that bigger houses have more surface area to leak out of; it wouldn't be fair to compare a huge house with a tiny house. So we have to figure out how much area there was for the heat to leak through. Unfortunately, there's no easy and accurate way to do this. Here is one simple way: find out how many square feet your house is. Most people already know that number for their houses.

Another way is to measure the length of the house and the width of the house. Most houses don't have simple shapes, so you'll have to fudge to get a decent approximate estimate of the length and width. Now multiply the length by the width to get the number of square feet of floor area in your house. For our example, let's say that the house is small and has 1,000 square feet of area

Now multiply the floor area of your house by 5; that'll get you a VERY rough estimate of the surface area of your house. This only works if your house is a perfect cube, but it's about the best we can do without getting really complicated. For our example, I get 5,000 square feet

Now at last you are ready to calculate your final result. Divide [the number of BTUs per hour per ºF] by [the surface area of your house]. In my example, I got 2,000 BTUs per hour per ºF divided by 5,000 square feet, so my final answer was 0.4 BTUs per hour per ºF per square foot.

Is that a good number or a bad number? Here's a way to compare the average insulation value that you got for your house to some other numbers:

motionless air: 0.5 BTUs per hour per ºF per square foot

insulation: 0.8 BTUs per hour per ºF per square foot
wood: about 2 BTUs per hour per ºF per square foot
cement: 6 BTUs per hour per ºF per square foot
glass: 22 BTUs per hour per ºF per square foot
soil: 30 BTUs per hour per ºF per square foot
copper: 8,000 BTUs per hour per ºF per square foot

Term.Title: Motor Scooters
Term.Text:
Motor scooters have always been popular all over the world, and they have been gaining popularity in America over the last ten years. As gasoline prices have soared, motor scooter sales have soared as well.

It's easy to understand why: motor scooters are fun, easy to use, and they get great mileage.

The standard motor scooter used the world over has a two-stroke 50cc engine, a top speed of about 35 mph, and boasts a gas mileage of about 80 mpg. Nowadays there are also much larger motor scooters with bigger engines, higher top speeds, and poorer gas mileage. They are meant for a single rider but can carry a second one at a lower top speed.

These machines are great for short trips on urban or suburban streets where the speed limit is 35 mph. They can be parked almost as easily as a bicycle, and in fact on many college campuses there's a place for parking scooters right next to the bicycle racks.

Motor scooters fall between mopeds (bicycles with tiny engines that require the rider to provide some of the power by pedaling) and motorcycles, which are much bigger, heavier, more powerful, faster – and get gas mileage barely better than a car. Most of the recent boom has been in motor scooters rather than mopeds or motorcycles.

People worry about how safe it is to drive a motor scooter. No doubt about it, crashing a motor scooter is a lot more dangerous than crashing a car, because you're out there in the open, unprotected. However, there is nothing intrinsically dangerous about motor scooters or motorcycles: an experienced and careful rider is every bit as safe as the driver of a car. It's true that you must be more careful on a scooter than in a car, but if you are careful, the chances of getting hurt are microscopic.

Here are the main reasons why people get hurt riding motor scooters:

No helmet You've got to be brainless to ride without a helmet – and you'll certainly be brainless soon enough.

DUI Guess what? Driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs is even more dangerous on a scooter than in a car, because you can't fall over and break your leg in a car.

Trusting car drivers The only state of mind that works while driving a scooter is paranoia. You have to assume that you are completely invisible or that every car on the road is out to run you down. "Defensive driving" has to be an understatement while driving a scooter.

Driving while young Youngsters love to ride on scooters, and youngsters are the most dangerous driving group in the world. What's really scary is the fact that a lot of kids too young to drive cars are allowed by their parents to drive scooters. This is really stupid: a large fraction of injuries on motor scooters are suffered by too-young drivers. Motor scooters don't cause youngsters to have more accidents, they just give them lots more opportunity to make fools of themselves. The upside of this is that idiot youngsters on motor scooters do less damage than idiot youngsters in cars. If you're in your teens and you want to drive a motor scooter, you damn well better grow up the second you sit down on that scooter.

Driving while male There's something exhilirating about feeling the wind in your face – and male exhiliration usually leads to male stupidity. One of the reasons that motor scooters have a better safety record than motorcycles is that more women drive motor scooters. If you are a young male and you want to drive a motor scooter or motorcycle, then you must constantly repeat to yourself while driving, "Is today a good day to die?"

I drove a small motorcycle during my youth. Starting at age 18, I drove a Honda 160, a small bike with a top speed of maybe 65 mph. I drove that thing all over creation, amassing an astounding 100,000 miles on it, while going through several crankshafts and lots of cylinder replacements. I have replaced almost every part on that bike except the frame. I still have it, and it still runs. More important, *I* still run. In all that driving, my worst accident resulted in only a skinned shin. I had at least two near-misses with bad drivers that would surely have been collisions had I been in a car. That little bike was agile! The monster bikes people ride these days are no more maneuverable than a Cadillac.

Term.Title: Nuclear Reactions
Term.Text:
Nuclear reactions are accomplished through fission, which is just a fancy word for "breaking up". Our story starts with a big fat uranium nucleus. Uranium nuclei are just about the largest nuclei you can find. Now, the nuclei of atoms are like water balloons: they're held together by internal force. Uranium nuclei are like water balloons that have been filled almost to bursting. They're wobbly. If a neutron just happens to hit a uranium nucleus, the impact is enough to break it (just like if you hit an overfilled water balloon with a rock.) When a uranium nucleus breaks – excuse me, fissions – it splits into two big pieces plus three neutrons, plus a lot of energy.

That energy ends up as heat. But the real fun comes from those three extra neutrons that get thrown out when the uranium nucleus fissions. They tear off into the wild blue yonder, but if there are other uranium nuclei in the neighborhood, they're likely to hit one or more of those nuclei. When those nuclei fission, they release even more neutrons, which hit more nuclei, and so on and so on until they've split up most of the uranium nuclei. This all happens very fast (like, in a few microseconds), and all that energy being released in a few microseconds makes what we call "a nuclear explosion".

But there's a catch to all this: in order for those neutrons to hit other uranium nuclei, those uranium nuclei have to be packed very tightly together to increase the chances of a neutron hitting a nucleus. It turns out that this is very hard to do – which is a good thing, because if it were easy, then anybody could build a nuclear bomb and usually "anybody" means "nasty people". Guess what kind of fun they could have with nuclear bombs?

One last thing: does the Second Amendment cover nuclear bombs?

Term.Title: Nuclear Safety
Term.Text:
If you turn off a flourescent light, it will continue to glow faintly for a few seconds afterward; it's still releasing energy. A nuclear reactor is exactly the same, except for two things: 1) it releases a lot more energy, and 2) it does so for a lot longer. When you first shut down a nuclear reactor, its power output immediately drops from 3000 megawatts to 200 megawatts. But after a week it's still generating about 6 megawatts of power Which means that you can't just turn off a nuclear reactor. You shut it down and then you wait weeks for it to burn out. During that time you must continue to pump cooling water in to keep it cool. But what happens if there's an accident at the plant that prevents you from pumping cooling water? This is exactly what happened at Three Mile Island in 1979 and at Fukushima Dai-Ichi in 2011. They shut down the reactors with no problem, but they were not able to get enough cooling water to the reactors.

This isn't supposed to happen. Every nuclear power plant is equipped with a variety of back-up systems to insure that it can continue to pump cooling water to the reactor core even after an accident. But at both Three Mile Island and Fukushima Dai-Ichi, the backup systems were only partly successful in supply cooling water. In both cases, the reactor cores melted.

A reactor core contains a humongous amount of nasty radioactive stuff, so it's critical that it not be allowed to escape from inside the plant. Reactors are kept inside large containment structures – great big buildings with thick steel-reinforced concrete walls. The plan is that, no matter how bad things are inside the containment structure, nothing bad will escape. This is exactly what happened at Three Mile Island: the reactor core melted, but the containment structure held it all inside safely and no dangerous levels of radioactive stuff escaped. At Fukushima Dai-Ichi, we're pretty sure that the containment structures mostly held firm, although one of the containment structures probably cracked.

But there was an even bigger problem with the spent fuel storage at Fukushima Dai-Ichi.

The accident at Chernobyl was completely different in nature, and much worse.

Term.Title: Ocean Fertilization
Term.Text:
Phytoplankton are tiny single-celled creatures that live on the surface of the ocean. Think of them as "teensy-weensy plants in the sea". They react to sunlight by growing in numbers. These phytoplankton are eaten by other microscopic creatures, which in turn are eaten by tiny shrimp, which are eaten by fish, which are eaten by larger fish, which we eat. In other words, phytoplankton sit at the base of the food pyramid in the ocean. Every living thing in the ocean ultimately gets its food from phytoplankton. Obviously, phytoplankton are crucial to the ecology of the ocean.

Occasionally, however, there can be too much of a good thing. When underwater currents drive sediments from the seafloor up to the surface, phytoplankton can go wild and reproduce like crazy. In such cases, we get huge phytoplankton blooms that cover the ocean for miles in a dense layer of phytoplankton. Eventually the phytoplankton are eaten or die off, and their tiny little bodies sink to the bottom of the ocean, taking with them the carbon that they pulled out of the atmosphere to build their bodies.

It just so happens that the main thing preventing phytoplankton blooms is the shortage of iron dissolved in the water. Phytoplankton can get everything they need to grow up strong and healthy in plain old seawater – except for iron. There isn't much iron in normal seawater, so phytoplankton blooms usually happen when some underwater currents suck sediment rich in iron up from the seafloor to the surface.

This means that, if we just add iron to the ocean, we'll get phytoplankton blooms, which will suck lots of carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere and drag it down to the bottom of the ocean, getting rid of it forever (as far as we're concerned).

But don't forget the first rule of environmental problems: there's always a catch. There are actually several catches to this idea. First, we really don't know how much carbon dioxide these phytoplankton blooms remove from the atmosphere. Second, sometimes phytoplankton blooms can kill other creatures in the ocean, disrupting the whole ecosystem for a hundred miles – and we aren't sure exactly how to cope with this possibility. However, there's a lot of research going on about this and we might actually figure out a good way to do it.

Term.Title: Organic Solar PV Tech
Term.Text:
All regular solar photovoltaic cells use silicon to convert sunlight into electricity. Silicon is nice, but organic molecules – the same kind of molecules that operate in all living creatures – are more efficient at the molecular level. Solar photovoltaic cells that rely on organic molecules should theoretically be capable of attaining higher efficiences. Scientists have built them in the laboratory, but they're not quite ready for commercialization: they're too expensive and their efficiency is too low.

What's especially neat about organic solar photocells is that they are extremely thin and can be manufactured in plastic sheets. That means that, once we get them working well enough, we can mass-produce them in huge quantities.

Even better, because they are in thin plastic sheets, they can be bent without damage. They can be fitted onto any curved surface, which will give them many applications where regular solar cells won't do.

Term.Title: Peak Load Management
Term.Text:
After reading the backgrounder on peak loads, you're probably wondering if there isn't any way to cut the costs arising from peak loads (keeping expensive power plants ready to go but not using them much). There are two particularly interesting solutions

The first is called peak load management. Suppose that you run a bakery in Phoenix, Arizona. The power company offers you a deal: if you'll let them turn off your ovens by remote control during the hottest parts of the day, they'll lower your electricity rates. That's a great deal, because you probably don't want to be running your ovens on the hottest days anyway. You can schedule your baking for the cooler hours of the early morning and just plan on not using them when it's hot. That's a great deal, isn't it?

It's also a great deal for the power company. They install a special power meter that has two connections: one to your regular stuff and a special one to your ovens. On a hot day, when they start to get near peak power, they can send an electrical signal down the power lines that will tell every one of those special power meters to turn off its special power line. All over the area, ovens and other electrical devices turn off, reducing the load. That way, the power company doesn't have to have so many extra power plants sitting around twiddling their thumbs, waiting for peak load. That saves everybody money.

However, that's not the only way to use peak load management. Many power companies ask their residential customers to sign up for the same deal, with the power company getting the right to turn off their air conditioning at peak load times. This is a great deal for the power company, because air conditioners are the biggest single contributor to peak demand. But it's a lousy deal for most people, because it means that the power company can shut down your air conditioning at the hottest time of the year. The shutdown will only last a few hours, but it's still bad news for most people.

A second way to handle peak load problems is with a scheme called peak load pricing. The idea is simple and clear: you have to pay the actual cost of the electricity that you use. Electricity during peak load time is more expensive to make (because they're relying on generators that they don't use often), so logically, you should pay more for that electricity. That's exactly what peak load pricing does. They'd install a new kind of electrical meter in your house, one that records not just how much electricity you use, but when you use it. Then they tell you what the prices are at different times of the day. Sometimes it's easier to simply set prices based on the temperature: on really hot days, everybody knows that electricity costs more.

The advantage of peak load pricing is that it's about as fair as you can get. Everybody knows that electricity is more expensive during peak times, so everybody will want to reduce their electricity use during those times – which will lower the demand for electricity during those times, reducing the size of the peak.

There is also a technology for handling peak load problems: pumped storage
