Term.Title: Peak Load Versus Base Load
Term.Text:
People want different amounts of electricity at different times. The law requires that power companies always supply enough electricity to meet the demand, no matter how much it varies. (After all, the power companies get to have monopolies, and this is part of the deal.) So power companies have to scramble to make sure that there's always enough power on tap to meet the demand of the people. At the same time, they must not make too much power, lest the voltage get too high and burn out every electric device that's turned on. In other words, they are running a system with a maximum level and a minimum level, and the difference between the maximum and the minimum is usually about 10% – and those numbers change steadily throughout the day.

The lowest demand for power is the bottom of the cycle: the lowest amount of electricity that they must generate. That's called base load. That's what they must supply 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year. On the hottest afternoon of the hottest day of the year, they have to supply peak load, which can be a lot more than the base load.

Here's their problem: base load is neat and clean: they just set up power plants big enough to supply the base load, and then let those power plants run all the time. Nuclear power plants are great for this, as are coal-burning power plants.

But for peak load, they have a more difficult problem: they have to have the power plants ready to go all the time, but they don't want to run those other power plants all the time: they want to run them only when the load gets higher than the base load. The problem is made trickier by the fact that different power plants have different operating limitations. So what they do is set up a bunch of different power plants, each of which has its own strengths and weaknesses. They operate the nuclear and coal plants 24/7/365 to cover the base load, then bring in natural gas turbines to handle some of the intermediate load, and hydroelectric plants to handle the peak demand. (Some utilities reverse this order, depending on how much hydroelectric power they have to work with.)

But here's the problem: the peak load power plants (natural gas plants and hydroelectric plants) aren't used all of the time. In fact, sometimes they sit there idly for days on end, not being used at all. These are expensive power plants, and somebody has to pay for them even when they're not actually running. Who do you think ends up paying for them: Santa Claus? Bill Gates? Enron? Nope. It's you and me who foot the bill for these unused power plants. It shows up in our electricity bills. So we end up paying for power plants that aren't used all the time. That's not very efficient, is it? Well, you gotta better idea?

As a matter of fact, people have come up with two ways to reduce those costs.

Term.Title: Peltier Cooler
Term.Text:
A Peltier cooler is a solid state device that moves heat from one of its sides to the other. When it's running, heat moves from the cold side to the hot side. It's an electronic heat pump with no moving parts. Compare this with the heat pumps we use for home heating and cooling and refrigerators we use today. They have moving parts: the compressor motor and the pump and the moving gas. They make noise and they break down. But a Peltier cooler has no moving parts, so there's nothing to wear out or break down.

There is one catch ("There's ALWAYS a catch!"): Peltier coolers are quite inefficient – only about 5% efficient, comparied with the 40% efficiency that mechanical heat pumps can achieve. So right now, Peltier coolers are only useful when you only need to cool something small. There are Peltier refrigerators that you can use while camping, but they eat up a lot of power and they don't get very cold.

So where's Mr. Science when you need him? Well, he's working on it, but we've got a long way to go before Peltier coolers are efficient enough to replace refrigerators. Don't hold your breath.

Term.Title: Pigovian Tax
Term.Text:
Arthur Cedric Pigou was an eminent English economist. How he got that way is anybody's guess, but my best guess is that he was mercilessly taunted by his schoolmates because of his name. Indeed, "pig-oo" is such an unpleasant word to pronounce that economists refer to his most enduring idea as Pigovian taxation, which sounds a little better.

The basic idea of Pigovian taxation concerns a tricky social problem. Suppose that a factory emits nasty pollution that hurts people: how should we deal with the problem? We can't ignore the damage done by the factory, but at the same time, we don't want to shut down the factory because it makes a useful economic contribution to society. How do we balance these two competing considerations?

Regulation: This is the most common approach. Government officials carefully study what reasonable solutions are available, and then require the factory to apply those reasonable solutions. Thus, the trade-off between economic benefits and personal injuries is made by government officials. This solution tends to be clumsy; it's impossible to write up regulations that apply well to every situation, so the regulations we end up with are usually too lenient for some factories and too harsh for others.

Tort: This is how most personal injuries are addressed. If you do something that hurts me, I sue you under tort law and, if I can prove that your action really did injure me, then I can demand that you pay me to reimburse me for my injuries. This works just fine when there's a single individual whom we can clearly identify as the victim of the emissions from a factory. But it seldom works with pollution, because it's impossible to identify a single victim. The harm is spread out among many people. Which brings us to:

Class action suits: This allows a large group of people (a "class") who have suffered small injuries from a large corporation to sue it collectively, and, if they prevail, collect a big chunk of change that's split up among the members of the class. The problem with class action suits is that lots of the money ends up going to lawyers, and many members of the class never benefit from it. It's ultimately an inefficient system, but it does serve to dissuade large corporations from doing the nasty things that they might get sued for.

Cap and Trade This system begins by setting a maximum amount of pollutant that is acceptable: the "cap". The cap is always set to equal the current amount being released. Every company that is releasing the pollutant automatically gets a free license to continue releasing the same amount of pollutant forever. It can sell the license, or parts of it, to other companies. The appeal of cap and trade is that it doesn't hurt industry right now; only when the industry grows does the cap start to pinch. Presumably, the companies releasing the pollutant will install better equipment to reduce their releases, permitting them to sell parts of their licenses to cover the cost of the new equipment. The downside of cap and trade, though, is that it legalizes the current releases of the pollutant, which may already be dangerously high, and it never allows future reductions if we learn that the pollutant is more dangerous than we had thought.

As you can see, none of these conventional approaches really does a good job of coping with the pollution problem created by the factory. That's where the Pigovian tax comes in; it's levied on any kind of damage to society or the environment. Take sulfur dioxide, for example. It damages the lungs of people, leading to emphysema and lung cancer. But it also damages the lungs of all creatures: dogs and cats and horses and cows, and vegetation as well: crops and trees and grass. It also damages the surfaces of buildings, corrodes the steel in bridges, and degrades paint. Its effects are widespread but, in isolation, tiny. So we have the government do some research and come up with an estimate of the total damages inflicted upon society by each ton of sulfur dioxide. Then it levies a tax on everybody who releases sulfur dioxide, measured in dollars per ton. You're perfectly free to emit as much sulfur dioxide as you wish, but you have to pay for the damages you inflict upon society.

There's no reason why a Pigovian tax must precisely equal the amount of damage inflicted by any pollutant. It could be less than the damage, if we felt that the industry creating the pollutant was important. It could be more than the amount of injury done, if we believe that the pollutant we're taxing has effects we just don't like. For example, of somebody emitted a pollutant that killed people's dogs, but did no other damage, we wouldn't just tax them to pay for the cost of the dogs – we'd probably want a much stiffer tax to discourage the release of such a pollutant.

The value of Pigovian taxes is that, of all the various remedies we can apply to environmental problems, Pigovian taxes are the most closely attuned to fundamental principles of capitalism and the free market. This is why they are more efficient than any other form of environmental control.

Besides, doesn't it make sense that you should stock your piggy bank with proceeds from a Pigovian tax? If instead you used an income tax, it would have to be put into an Inky bank, and a sales tax would have to go into a Sally bank.

Term.Title: Poles Vs Equator
Term.Text:
You may have wondered, "Why does the greenhouse effect cause more warming at the poles than at the equator?" The answer has to do with both water vapor and carbon dioxide. At the equator, there's lots of water vapor in the air (it's really humid at the equator). But at the poles, it's very dry, because cold air cannot hold much water vapor. Since water vapor is a very powerful greenhouse gas, any additional carbon dioxide at the equator will have its effects buried by the much stronger effects of water vapor. So, more carbon dioxide doesn't have much effect at the equator.

It's a completely different story at the poles. There's almost no water vapor in the air there, so there's no greenhouse effect to speak of. But if you add carbon dioxide to the air there, then it starts producing a greenhouse effect.

In other words, the greenhouse effect is already pretty much maxed out at the equator, so more carbon dioxide there doesn't have much effect. But there's almost no greenhouse effect at the poles, so even a tiny amount of carbon dioxide has a big effect.

Term.Title: Poor World People
Term.Text:
Seven billion people live on this planet; two billion enjoy a comfortable life, never worrying about getting the basics of life. Another two billion are moving out of poverty; but three billion people live on less than $2.50 a day, scratching out a living as best they can.

They can never be certain that they'll have food to eat in a week's time, they get by with simple clothing and primitive housing. They can count themselves lucky if they have access to clean water. Their neighborhoods often reek of raw sewage because they have no sewage treatment systems. They might have some electricity, and perhaps a neighbor with a cell phone they can use when necessary. Not many of them can read and write.

In many poor countries, life expectancy is less than 50 years. One in ten babies dies in childbirth. The mother dies in one of every 200 childbirths. Every year, seven million children under the age of 5 die, almost all of them in poor countries. Two-thirds of these people have no toilets or latrines. One billion people have no way to get safe drinking water; millions of them die each year from easily preventable water-borne diseases.

Term.Title: Power Plant Regularity
Term.Text:
Every kind of power plant has its own special needs and capabilities that the people running the grid must take into account.

Nuclear power plants are stubborn: they work best when they run at full power 24/7/365. Once you get a nuclear power plant running at full steam, you either leave it there or you shut it down completely. In fact, one of the mistakes that led to the nuclear accident at Chernobyl was that the operators were raising and lowering the power levels of the reactor. That's a no-no.

Coal-burning power plants and oil-burning power plants are more forgiving, but they still work best when you just run them flat out 24 hours a day. Yes, you can raise and lower the power levels, but you can't just do it willy-nilly: you have to bring the power up or down slowly so that the temperatures inside don't change too quickly. With a big power plant like that, sudden changes in temperature can cause pipes to warp, bend, and twist. That's not good.

Natural gas power plants are really good for fast changes. That's because they use a different turbine system that can more easily go up and down in power.

Hydro-electric power plants (dams with generators) are probably the most flexible of all generating systems. You can turn them on and off in something like a minute.

Solar and wind energy systems have a different problem: you can't control when they go on and off: the weather does! When the sun is out or it's windy, they make lots of electricity. When the sun is down, or when it's cloudy, or when there's no wind, they don't make electricity. This makes life especially difficult for the grid operators, because they have to take the addition of that energy into account into their planning, but they can't control how much or little electricity it makes at any given moment.

Suppose that you're driving a car down the street, and your little brat of a kid has sneakily rigged up a string to the gas pedal and is sitting in the back seat, pulling on the string every now and then. One minute the car is speeding up for no reason, and the next minute it's slowing down for no reason. It would be pretty hard to drive the car, wouldn't it? That's sorta like the problem that grid operators face with solar and wind energy. It's not as bad as the brat with the string, because the ups and downs take place more slowly, and it's possible to get weather data in advance that will warn you about unexpected changes. But it's definitely a headache, and ultimately it imposes its own special costs on electricity.

Term.Title: Pumped Storage
Term.Text:
One of the biggest pains for electricity companies is that you can't store electricity, at least not in any usable amounts. Even big batteries don't store enough energy to make much of an impression on the grid; if we tried to use batteries to make up shortfalls, they'd run out of juice in seconds. This is why peak load is so expensive: power companies can't save electricity to prepare for peak load. They have to be generating it at the instant it's needed.

But there is, in fact, another way to store electricity, and it's called pumped storage. Suppose you run a power company and you have a dam with a big lake, with generators at the bottom of the dam making electricity. You realize that a generator is also a motor: if you spin the shaft with some force, electricity comes out, and if you put electricity in, it spins by itself.

In a hydroelectric dam, the water falls into a huge, super-efficient water wheel, forcing it to spin. The water wheel is connected to a generator that makes electricity. But you could just as easily go the other way: use lots of electricity to force the water wheel to turn in the other direction, pumping water back up into the reservoir.

In other words, when you have extra electricity to spare, you can use it to pump water up into the reservoir. Later, at peak demand time, you can let the water in the reservoir come out, turning the generator and making electricity. In other words, your system saves electricity!

As always, there are a few catches. First, you can only pump so much water into the reservoir; pump too much and it spills over the top of the dam. The total amount of water you can store in the reservoir limits how much electricity you can store.

The second catch is that you have to have a reservoir at the bottom of the dam to hold all the water that you intend to pump up into the upper reservoir. A normal dam just lets the water that comes out flow down the river; you need to save enough water for later use.

The second catch is that about 25% of the energy is lost in each cycle. That's not a killer problem, but it is something to be aware of.

The real limitation on using pumped storage is the difficulty of finding a good place to have the two reservoirs. You need a high place for one reservoir and a low place for the other reservoir – and they have to be close together, like, within half a mile of each other. Most mountain ranges just aren't that steep: you won't find many big lakes that are really high and within half a mile of another big lake that's, say, a thousand feet lower.

Fortunately, we can take advantage of fortuitous geography to create usable sites for pumped storage. The most common arrangement is to dig out a big reservoir on a hill or mountain above an existing lake or reservoir. Often dammed lakes or reservoirs are in mountainous terrain where there are plenty of good sites to build upper reservoirs. Still, digging out a complete reservoir from scrach can be an expensive proposition.

Worldwide, we have a total of about 100 gigaWatts of pumped storage capacity; that's about as much as 100 individual big power plants can make. Europe leads the way with 37% of the total; Japan comes next with 25% of the total; and the USA comes in third with 20% of the total.

Term.Title: Rad Waste Disposal
Term.Text:
Some people think that we don't know how to store radioactive waste from nuclear power plants. This isn't true. The technology for radioactive waste disposal has been known for decades, and lots of engineering tests have been carried out to verify how well it works.

The first step in the process is called vitrification, which just means "sealing it up inside glass". That doesn't mean putting it inside a glass bottle, it means actually mixing powdered radioactive waste into molten glass. We get thousands of little glass pellets, each one containing a small amount of radioactive waste inside. Fortunately, water doesn't dissolve glass, which is good, because otherwise you'd get water on your shirt every time you tried to drink some in a glass. In fact, almost nothing dissolves glass: sulfuric acid, nitric acid, nothing. Which means that, once the glass is buried, none of the radioactive stuff inside will dissolve into groundwater and then travel to the surface.

Next, we put the glass pellets inside a big steel barrel. These steel barrels have been manufactured to withstand all sorts of damage without cracking. They're not indestructible, but you'd need something extremely powerful to crack open one of these babies.

Finally, we bury the barrels deep underground. There are about a dozen test facilities around the world where the stability of the surrounding rock is being investigated. There are also another dozen or so working repositories now under construction. The USA has an excellent site at Yucca Mountain in Nevada, which has undergone extensive testing and has been shown to be geologically ideal for long-term storage of radioactive waste. However, people living in Nevada don't like the idea of a nuclear waste repository in their state, no matter how safe, and have nixed the whole thing.

Term.Title: Resources And Price
Term.Text:
In ancient times, you didn't have to dig for coal: you could find it lying around on the ground in the right places. Ancient peoples used tar, bitumen, and oil from oil seeps that come right up to the surface. But as the easy sources were used up, people started to dig deeper to get to the coal and oil. We've been doing that ever since, going further and deeper to get our resources.

Obviously, the deeper you dig, and the more widely you explore, the more resource you'll get. But digging deeper and exploring further cost more money. This establishes a basic relationship between the supply of any resource and its price: the higher the price, the greater the supply.

Thus, if we make a graph of the supply of a resource against its price, like the one shown here, we see curves that curve upwards, providing more and more energy at higher prices.

But the curves for the fossil fuels only curve upwards at first; they're really bell-shaped curves. That's because there's only so much fossil fuel in the ground; eventually we'll reach the point where digging deeper doesn't produce much more fuel. We're already close to that point with oil; that point is called peak oil.

Even the nonrenewable energy sources, such as solar energy, follow bell curves. After all, once we have completely covered the surface of the earth with solar panels, there won't be any more sunlight to harvest. But that day is so far away that it's reasonable to think that it will never come.

Windows are another big source of heat loss.
Finally, home lighting is another area where you can make big savings in money and energy.

Term.Title: Rich World People
Term.Text:
Two billion of the earth's population of seven billion enjoy a comfortable lifestyle. They have all the food they want – indeed, they suffer more from obesity than malnutrition. They have lots of clothes to wear, most of them have a car and a mobile phone. They watch television, go out the movies, surf the Internet, and play computer games.

The average American uses about 300 gigaJoules every year. That's enough energy to put 5 tons of stuff into orbit around the earth. That's enough to drive an average American car twice around the globe. That's enough energy to run an incandescent 100 watt light bulb for a hundred years. Yep, we use a lot of energy.

The average German uses only 176 gigaJoules; the average Chinese uses 47 gigaJoules, less than one-sixth what the average American uses. At the bottom end of the scale come countries like Bangladesh and Senegal, which use less than 10 gigaJoules per person per year. However, there are some countries that use more energy than we do: Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates, rich with oil and using lots of air-conditioning, use about 430 gigaJoules per person per year. The people in the freezing country of Iceland use 500 gigaJoules per year to heat their houses. And the world record, at 900 gigaJoules per year, is held by the tiny and fabulously wealthy country of Qatar.

We gobble up a lot of other resources. Americans use more than 100 gallons of water per person each day; people in Mozambique use only about 5 gallons of water per person per day. Americans use more than 300 pounds of plastic per year; Africans use only 22. We eat 275 pounds of meat each year, but people in Bangladesh eat about 3 pounds per year. The list goes on and on, but the basic fact is simple: people in the Rich World use up most of the resources on this planet.

We are also the biggest polluters. Americans emit about 18 tons of carbon dioxide per person each year; people in poor countries in Africa emit only about a hundred pounds of carbon dioxide per person per year.

Term.Title: Solar Cells
Term.Text:
Solar cells are special pieces of silicon that convert sunlight into electricity. The electricity they produce is called solar photovoltaic energy, or just solar PV for short. Here's how they work:

We start with a happy-go-lucky photon from the sun (a photon is a particle of light) comes sailing down to the earth. The photon hits the solar cell and penetrates a short distance (a few millionths of an inch) into the cell. It eventually collides with an atom inside the solar cell, knocking loose an electron. This kind of thing happens all the time with all kinds of different substances. Normally, the electron wanders around for a little while and eventually finds its way back home. But the solar cell is made of special stuff that makes it impossible for the electron to get back home. That special stuff consists of two different kinds of silicon joined together. Where they meet, they form a barrier zone that an electron can pass through in one direction, but not the other way. It's kind of like a one-way turnstile: once you go in, you can't come back out.

At the bottom of the solar cell is an aluminum plate that conducts electricity. When the electron hits that plate, it zips right through it, coming out of the solar cell in a wire. The electron wants so much to get home that it is willing to move through our circuits as electricity, doing useful things for us, in order to reach the wire that will take it back to the top of the solar cell, where it can travel back downward to get home.

Some people think that this is cruel to electrons. What do you think?

Term.Title: Solar Water Heating
Term.Text:
The simplest and most effective way to use solar energy is to use it to heat water. The technology has been available for decades, it works well and is reliable. All it takes is a big copper plate (painted black) inside an insulated box with a window, facing the sun. You weld some copper pipes to the big black copper plate, and then connect the pipes to a water tank above the solar panel. The sun heats up the black pipe, and the heat is transferred through the copper to the water in the pipes. That water becomes warmer and, because it's warmer, it rises in the pipes, moving into the water tank. The coolest water in the water tank flows downward into the bottom of the water pipes inside the solar panel. Thus, water slowly circulates through the system, getting hotter and hotter until it reaches its maximum temperature. When you want hot water, you turn on the tap and the hot water from the tank flows out your tap.

People have been using solar water heating for a long time. Armies have used metal drums painted black as a quick and portable means to make warm water for showers. People have been selling solar water heating systems for homes since the 1970s. They really do work, they really do save money, and they really are reliable.

Term.Title: Spent Fuel Pools
Term.Text:
Like batteries, fuel rods don't last forever; after a while they lose most of their usable energy and they have to be replaced with fresh fuel rods. What do we do with the used-up fuel rods?

These things are really dangerous – they're full of extremely radioactive materials. This is what we call radioactive waste and it is imperative that it never, ever gets loose in the environment. To accomplish this, we need to build long-term radioactive waste repositories. However, we have a problem doing this: nobody wants a long-term radioactive waste disposal in their back yard. Whenever the government tries to set up a disposal site, the local people scream bloody murder and chase the government away. So we don't have any working radioactive waste disposal sites. Meanwhile, nuclear reactors all over the world are making lots and lots of radioactive waste. Where does it all go?

We leave them at the nuclear power plant, that's where. You see, when those used-up fuel rods come out of the reactor, they're so dangerously radioactive that it's not safe to ship them anywhere. Instead, we have a big concrete pool right next to the reactor, filled with water. We put the spent fuel rods into that pool. The water serves two purposes: first, it gobbles up all the radiation coming out of the fuel rods, so the workers are safe. Second, it cools the fuel rods, which continue to generate a lot of heat for months. After a few years, the fuel rods have cooled down enough for us to ship them to a safe place.

But because there's no safe place to send them to, we just keep them where they are. Those pools were designed to hold only a few sets of fuel rods, temporarily, and for decades now, we've been stuffing ALL of the spent fuel rods into them, which really overloads the cooling systems.

So we just keep postponing action and the most dangerous radioactive waste in the world stays inside pools of water, and we hope that nothing goes wrong. It didn't work at Fukushima.

That spooky blue color in the photo is called Cerenkov radiation. It's just blue light, but physicists think it's really cool, because it happens when subatomic particles (electrons, protons, neutrons, that kind of thing) come screaming out of the spent fuel and enter the water. The speed of light in water is less than the speed of light in the fuel, so the subatomic particles have to give up some energy so that they can stay below the speed limit of the speed of light. The energy they give up is the blue light we call Cerenkov radiation. I haven't the faintest idea who Mr. Cerenkov was.

Term.Title: Stratospheric Sulfate
Term.Text:
Here's an idea: let's fly airplanes high up into the stratosphere where they dump tons and tons of sulfate compounds in a fine mist. Those compounds would form an aerosol that would slightly block sunlight. This would counter the greenhouse effect created by all the carbon dioxide we release. Injecting a million tons of such sulfates each year should be sufficient to cancel out the effects of the carbon dioxide we emit every year.

They calculate that this would cost maybe $50 billion per year. Since climate change could end up costing us maybe as much as a trillion dollars per year, this really does sound like a bargain.

But there is a catch (first rule of environmental problems: there's always a catch). In this case, the catch is that we don't know what the side effects would be. There's a chance that it could lead to nasty droughts in some places; if that happens, could the victims of the drought sue the people spraying the sulfates for a few billion bucks? Also, there's a chance that this would lead to ozone depletion, which would damage agriculture and cause more cases of skin cancer (but only among light-skinned people).

This option is a huge gamble. It just might work. Or it just might create even worse problems. Are you feeling lucky today, punk?

Term.Title: Strip Mining
Term.Text:
The safest and most efficient way to dig coal, if it's not too deep, is to remove the soil over it and then just shovel it up. The machine that shovels up the coal is called a dragline, and the biggest one in the world is the Bagger 288, capable of digging up enough coal in one day to fill 2,400 railroad cars. This kind of mechanization has made strip mining very efficient.

In the USA, strip mining is practiced in a great many states, with some of the biggest operations being in Wyoming and neighboring states, and West Virginia and its neighboring states. The photograph shows a strip mine in Wyoming.

The most controversial form of strip mining involves mountain top removal. West Virginia is hilly (well, Easterners would call it "mountainous"), and many of those mountains have a thick layer of coal a hundred feet or more down from the top. So they use bulldozers to push the dirt off the top of the mountain, leaving just the coal layer, which they then scoop up.

When they're done, they have to fix the mess they made. They bulldoze a lot of dirt back and smooth everything out into a flat area where once there was a big hill (or small mountain, if you're an Easterner). They then pack everything down, put soil on top, and plant and water grass on the new flat spot they made.

Advocates of this kind of mining argue that they restore the land environmentally, and they convert useless hills ("mountains!") into usable land. They point out that these new lands have been put to all sorts of uses: golf courses, local airports, and trailer parks, among other things. Such uses would have been impossible beforehand, they argue.

Opponents point out that mountain top removal generates millions of tons of loose rock and dirt that are piled into local valleys, contaminating the local streams. Although the mining companies plant grass on the new land, trees don't grow well in the poor soil, so you end up replacing a tree-covered hill ("MOUNTAIN!!!") with a grassy flat-top.

Term.Title: The Grid
Term.Text:
Electricity is manufactured in power plants, and then brought to your home by big wires. Sounds pretty simple, right? Well, it isn't. There are a jillion factors that make it difficult to connect your house to the power plant. The first is the fact that some of the electricity is lost moving down the wires. Second, the amount of energy that people want changes through the day. Third, people in different areas want different amounts of electricity, and different power plants are in different places. And fourth, different kinds of power plants produce electricity in differing amounts at different times. See: 1, 2, 3, a jillion. What'd I tell you?

The map shows the electrical grid for the United States. It shows all the power lines carrying power from one place to another. As you can see, it's quite complicated: we need a lot of transmission lines in the east, where there are lots of people crowded together. There aren't that many people in the mountain states, so there isn't much need for power and not so many power lines. The people crowded along the West Coast use of lots of power, and so they need a dense network of power lines.

Term.Title: The Technological Fix
Term.Text:
A hundred years ago, most short-haul transportation was powered by horses. Inside cities, thousands of horses pulled freight, buses, and taxis. New York City had 100,000 horses using its streets, depositing 2.5 million pounds of manure on its streets every day. A huge force of street cleaners was required to keep the streets passable. Every year, the increasing number of people and goods moving through the city required more and more horses; a mountain of horse shit threatened to bury New York City. Hands were wrung; eyebrows were furrowed; nobody could conceive a solution to the problem.

Twenty years later, the problem was all but solved. The internal combustion engine had allowed trucks and automobiles to replace horses. Cars, unlike horses, don't leave shit on the ground (but they do fart pollution into the air, a problem that grew as more and more cars were used).

Fifty years ago, the world seemed doomed to starvation. Three billion mouths had to be fed, yet the food supply wasn't keeping up with human fertility. Experts warned that starvation on such a scale would lead to civil wars, rebellions, insurgencies, and even international wars. They called it "The Population Bomb". But how could disaster be averted? The world's farms were already running at full steam; there wasn't any new land to open up for new farms.

Fifty years later, we have seven billion mouths, and while malnutrition remains a serious problem, we have increased agricultural productivity so much that we really could feed everybody if only we had better distribution systems for food. This was made possible by the Green Revolution. By developing higher-yield crops, crops that could grow with less water, and improved fertilizers, herbicides, and pesticides, scientists were able to dramatically increase agricultural productivity and defuse the Population Bomb.

The history of the last century sparkles with stories like these: seemingly intractable problems solved by the wonders of modern science. It's almost like a fairy tale: the Evil Monster is just about to devour the Fair Maiden when Super-Scientist arrives to save the day. We've seen this story play out so many times that we've started to take it for granted. All over the world, Fair Maidens are checking their watches and tapping their feet, wondering aloud, is that damn Super-Scientist going to take all day to get here?

Some people go so far that they don't see much need to worry about problems like energy or climate change or pollution; they figure that science will surely solve the problem for us someday. This attitude is called The Technological Fix: for every problem, there's a technological fix. "What, me worry?" they say; "The scientists will surely fix it any day now."

And, most of the time, they're right! Yep, science has saved our butts over and over again. But the fact that science can solve most of our problems doesn't mean that it can solve all of our problems. There are plenty of problems that science hasn't been able to solve.

For example, take traffic congestion. For the last fifty years, commuters have had to sit in traffic jams for hours on end, crawling inch by inch to get where they're going. We build new freeways, bigger freeways, add more ramps and special traffic control systems – and we're still getting there no faster than we were fifty years ago. All the super-duper science and technology in the world has accomplished very little when it comes to traffic congestion.

Or how about fusion energy? Fifty years ago, we were sure that someday soon, we'd have nuclear reactors using fusion energy. They'd use the hydrogen in plain water as fuel, and there's enough water on this planet to keep us rolling in fusion energy for millions of years. Electricity would be so cheap and plentiful, we'd never have to worry about energy again. Well, fifty years have passed and we STILL don't have a working fusion reactor, and we're not even close.

The list of problems that science has failed to solve is long: we haven't found a cure for cancer, or even the common cold. We still don't have cars that fly, and we still can't talk to computers in plain English (although we're starting to get close with technologies like Siri). Solar cells are getting cheaper every day, but back in 1975 we were sure they'd be dirt cheap within twenty years. Despite all of our grand technological advances, our main source of electricity all over the world comes from burning old-fashioned, low-tech coal. Electric cars have been around for a hundred years, but we still don't have an affordable electric car with acceptable performance (although again, we're starting to get close).

The moral of this story is simple: Super-Scientist does a good job, and he often shows up in the nick of time to save Fair Maiden, but she'd be a fool to get herself into precarious situations expecting Super-Scientist to swoop down and save her every time. Sometimes, Super-Scientist is busy saving somebody else's goose; sometimes, he's sitting on the toilet; and sometimes, his super-powers just aren't enough to save the day.

Term.Title: Thermal Equilibrium
Term.Text:
Equilibrium is just the snotty word for "balance", so thermal equilibrium is a situation where all the heat is in balance. For example, consider the earth. We've got sunlight pouring in – about 200 petaWatts worth of heat power hitting the earth. That warms the earth. But, remember, the earth has heat, and so it emits infrared radiation. How much does it emit? Normally, it emits exactly the same amount of energy in the form of infrared light out into space. How can we know that? Because the earth is (almost) in equilibrium. The amount of heat going out has to equal the amount of heat coming in. Otherwise, the temperature of the earth would change.

Here's an example: suppose that the sun were suddenly to get twice as bright, so that it was sending us not 200 petaWatts of heat power, but 400 petaWatts of heat power. All that extra heat would cause the earth to start getting hotter, right? The temperature would go up. But here's the trick: remember how (in the page about Thermal Radiation) I told you that the hotter an object is, the more radiation it emits (and the bluer that radiation is)? If the earth were to heat up because of all that extra sunlight, its temperature would rise and it would therefore emit more infrared radiation. As long as there was more sunlight energy coming in than infrared energy going out, the earth's temperature would continue to rise. But eventually it has to rise far enough that the amount of infrared radiation going out is equal to the amount of sunlight energy coming in. At that point, the earth will be back in thermal equilibrium and temperatures will remain constant.

It works the other way around, too. Suppose that the sun were to suddenly get only half as bright as it is now, so that instead of 200 petawatts of sunlight coming in, we had only 100 petawatts of sunlight coming in. The earth would still be radiating 200 petawatts, so there would be more infrared energy leaving the earth than sunlight coming in. But if the earth is losing heat energy into space, then its total heat content goes down: in other words, it cools. Its temperature goes down, which means that it emits less than 200 petawatts. So long as the amount of infrared radiation that it emits is greater than the amount of sunlight coming in, the earth will continue to cool until it reaches a new thermal balance – oops, thermal equilibrium

Thus, the earth automatically adjusts its temperature to stay in balance with the sunlight coming in – and it does it all without a single computer!

But this is only the beginning of the story. It's what we call a first approximation: a short, simple version of the truth, that leaves out messy details so that you can understand it. Now we're going to start throwing in messy details. The first messy detail is absorption.

Term.Title: Thermal Power Plant
Term.Text:
Most big power plants (coal, oil, nuclear, and natural gas) operate by using the fuel as a source of heat. The heat boils water into steam. Now, when water boils into steam, it expands to 1700 times its original volume, and if we keep it bottled up inside pipes, that increases the pressure inside the pipes. We run the pipes into a turbine, and the steam makes the turbine spin. The turbine is connected to a generator, which makes electricity. Then wires take the electricity right here into your computer. Just think: the electricity within a fraction of an inch of your fingertips is coming from a bunch of superheated steam far away.

But we're not done yet. After it leaves the turbine, it goes into a condenser, which turns it back into water. Then we pump it right back into the boiler to repeat the cycle.

The condenser is able to cool the steam and condense it back into water because it has a steady supply of cool water provided by hyperbolic cooling towers which cool tremendous amounts of water without a single moving part.

And that's how power plants work.

Term.Title: Thermal Radiation
Term.Text:
Thermal Radiation: sounds pretty scary, right? Like, maybe, radioactive monsters that are hot, or something like that, right? Well, no, it's actually nowhere near as much fun as that; in fact, thermal radiation is a common, everyday thing that you already know about, you just haven't heard the snazzy name that makes you sound like you're smart when you use it.

Anything that has any heat in it at all will radiate thermal radiation. You can feel that thermal radiation on your face when you stand close to a fire. The hotter the fire, the more thermal radiation you feel. But high temperature does more than make more thermal radiation – it makes bluer thermal radiation. In other words, as the temperature of something gets higher, its color becomes bluer. If you have an electric stovetop, you can see this happening: turn on the stove to its highest temperate and watch closely. The first you'll see is a dark red color on the coils; then the color will become brighter and more like normal red. As it gets really hot, it starts to look orange. If you had a turbo-charged stovetop, then you could raise the temperature even higher and the coils would become yellow-hot, then blue-hot. However, that temperature would be so high that the stove would melt and you'd burn your house down. And by the way, if you do perform this experiment, please do not sit down on the stove, lick the coils, touch them with your hand, or other such idiocy. Yes, there really are people stupid enough to try things like that!

Because the earth has heat, it also emits thermal radiation. Fortunately, you don't have to be careful when walking on the earth's surface ("Ouch! Ouch! The thermal radiation is getting me!"), because that thermal radiation takes the form of infrared radiation, which our eyes cannot see. (If you think about it, it's a good thing that we can't see infrared radiation; if we could, then everywhere we looked, we'd see thermal radiation and the whole world would look like a brightly lit pure white room.) So the earth is constantly emitting infrared light out into space. It's all part of the process called thermal equilibrium.

Term.Title: Tiny Cars
Term.Text:
America is the only country in the world where you don't see many tiny cars; Americans regard such cars with derision. It's a shame, because these little cars are great ways to get around. The car shown in the picture is called a "SmartCar". It's a two-seater that gets about 40 mpg and costs around $14,000. This car is no slouch, either – it has a top speed of around 90 mph, and it can easily maintain 65 mph fully loaded.

Little cars like this swarm all over European, Latin American, and Asian roads; the total number of such cars might be as high as 100 million. They're popular because they're so practical. They all get great gas mileage, they carry two people plus some spare space for groceries, they're quick, and they're easy to park. All in all, little cars are better for many people the world over.

Few Americans realize just how expensive their cars are. The average cost of owning a car in the US is about $8,000 per year. Of that, roughly $2,000 goes to gasoline. Moreover, big cars cost more and depreciate faster. When you add up all the costs, a small car costs about $2000 per year less than a big car.So why don't Americans like them? American culture puts the automobile on a pedestal. Big, powerful, fast cars are idolized. A lot of American men think that their car reflects their manhood: real men drive big cars. Does the size of one's bicycle reflect your manhood? Does the size of your handkerchief say "I'm a REAL man"?

Bigger is not necessarily better; it's just bigger. In the case of cars, bigger usually means faster and more powerful, but it also means more expensive to purchase, more expensive to operate, and harder to park.

I have a really big hat that I sometimes wear. One day I got into an elevator and this other fellow strode in wearing a cowboy hat. The elevator doors closed and we started moving. There was dead silence as we rode up. Just before the doors opened at my floor, I turned to the other guy and said, "Mah hat is BIGGER than yore hat!" Then I got off the elevator.

Is yore car bigger than the other guy's?

Term.Title: Transmission Losses
Term.Text:
All you need to carry electricity is a wire, but, as with everything on this sad planet that clouds our sunny days, there's a catch: some of the electricity is lost in transmission down the wire. When electricity travels through wires, it heats them slightly, reducing the amount of electricity that comes out the other end of the wire. If it's a LOT of electricity and a LITTLE wire, then the wire can actually melt.

When I was a kid, I used to take apart little electric motors and unwind the fine wire inside, then stick both ends of the wire into the electrical outlet. The wire would turn bright red and vaporize – what fun! (We didn't have videogames back then.) Anyway, if you try to do this yourself, you're a drooling idiot, just like I was. I did all sorts of idiotic things when I was a kid. I will never understand how I survived my childhood.

Anyway, getting back to electricity transmission: the most effective technique to reduce transmission losses is to use higher voltages, which lose less energy to heat. For many years, power transmission lines have used voltages of 200,000 volts and higher. But higher voltages are trickier to work with, and so most transmission lines use something between 200,000 and 500,000 volts.

Even so, we lose about 6% of all the electricity we produce to transmission losses. That lost electricity is worth about $30 billion every year. Obviously, anything we can do to reduce that loss will save us a lot of money. One of the best ways to do this is with HVDC: High Voltage DC lines.

Term.Title: Turbine
Term.Text:
Take a child's pinwheel, as shown in the upper left. Blow on it, and it spins. Now scale things up: instead of blowing air out of your mouth, direct a blast of superheated steam at it. It spins really fast before disintegrating, doesn't it? OK, so let's make it bigger and stronger, like the monster steel thing in the upper right. That could easily handle the steam, couldn't it? And it would turn really fast, right? This is what we call a turbine A turbine converts the energy of high-pressure steam into spinning energy. That's all it does. This kind of turbine is used in power plants that burn coal, oil, or natural gas; in nuclear power plants, geothermal plants, and solar thermal plants.

But turbines can also work in the other direction, converting spinning energy into air motion. When they operate like this, we call them fans. The biggest and most powerful of these are turbofan jet engines, like the one in the bottom of the picture.

Term.Title: Underground Mining
Term.Text:
Some coal is so deep underground that the only way to reach it is to dig a deep mine. Once you get to the coal, it's pretty easy to mine, because coal is soft. Machines with big teeth cut into the coal, which falls onto a conveyor belt that takes it up to the surface. Long gone are the days when miners swung pickaxes.

Underground mining used to be extremely dangerous. Over 100,000 coal miners were killed in mining accidents in the USA during the 20th century. However, with proper safety precautions, mining can be made much safer. Nowadays only a few dozen miners are killed in the USA every year. However, there is a more insidious killer of coal miners: lung disease, which strikes 4% of American coal miners every year. Although it is not necessarily fatal, it always shortens a person's lifespan.

In other countries without strict safety requirements, however, underground coal mining kills many more people. In China, by far the world's largest producer of coal, perhaps 10,000 miners die each year.

Underground coal mining has only one significant environmental impact: subsidence. After the miners have finished mining all the coal in a section, they permit it to collapse onto itself; this is done for safety purposes. All the rock over the section shifts downward, and the surface drops as well. With a big mine, this leaves a large, shallow depression in the ground. This depression prevents water from draining away properly. Compared to surface mining, this is small beans.

Term.Title: Variable Demand
Term.Text:
Twas one in the morning, and all through the house, not a machine was running, except for maybe the refrigerator, and the alarm clock, and the computer, and the cellphone charger, and some other things. But when the people woke up, they turned on lights, ran the coffeemaker, and used more electricity. In the afternoon, it got hot, so they turned on the air conditioning, using a LOT more electricity. When evening came, they used the oven to make dinner, watched TV, played videogames, and did a bunch of other things needing electricity. But as evening turned to night, they started going to bed, and they used less and less electricity.

Now multiply this by a million families in a million homes, and imagine that you're the guy running the power plant who has to provide all the electricity. During the night, you don't want to generate much electricity: if you do make too much electricity, the voltage will get too high and people's TVs, computers, microwave ovens, and videogames will burn out, and the videogamers will come and get you. So you have to make only a little electricity in the middle of the night.
But when morning comes, you want to start increasing the amount of electricity you generate, and steadily increasing it all through the day. Normally, you'll have to make the most electricity in the late afternoon, but it depends alot on the season and location.

Big deal, you say: he just has to turn the volume dial on his power plant, turning it up or down as needed. Sorry, power plants don't work that way. Different kinds of power plants operate differently and have to be carefully managed.

This variation in demand for electricity creates one of the nastiest problems with electricity: the difference between peak load and base load. That difference is the cause of additional costs.

There are about 500 grids in the US, most of them are connected together in a single super-grid. Each separate grid has its own control room with grid operators who constantly monitor the flow of power through the grid. They handle changes by turning on and off their hydroelectric or natural gas power plants (if they have any). They also buy or sell power with other grids. Every control room is protected against terrorists and has a big supply of antacid pills.

Term.Title: Walking
Term.Text:
The average American walks about 2.5 miles per day. By contrast, people in Australia and Switzerland walk about 5 miles per day, and Japanese walk about 3.5 miles per day. Amish people, who don't drive cars, walk an average of 8 miles per day. Doctors recommend about 5 miles of walking per day as a good rule of thumb for healthy living. This is one reason why so many Americans are obese: they just don't get enough exercise. So, the best reason to walk more is for your own health.

But walking instead of driving also saves energy, especially for short trips. When a car is first started and is still warming up, it doesn't get as good mileage as when it's fully warmed up.

Moreover, what with all the time spent dealing with the particular delays of automobile travel (getting in the car, starting it up, backing it out, waiting for traffic, finding a parking place, and so on), the speed advantage of a car is cancelled out for short trips. How long should a trip be in order to justify taking the car instead of walking? The answer, of course, depends upon your own tastes. I live up in the mountains, and my mailbox is half a mile away from my house. I never take the car to get the mail; I always walk. My nearest neighbor is about 3/4 of a mile away from my house; I usually drive to get there, although on nice days I'll sometimes take the shorter walking route through the woods.

Lastly, there's the most important reason to walk instead of drive: it's just a lot more pleasant.

Term.Title: Water Turbine
Term.Text:
A water turbine converts the energy of moving water into spinning energy. Water turbines are used inside hydroelectric dams to turn generators that make electricity. They're huge, so that they can handle enormous amounts of water.

Just like regular turbines, water turbines work in both directions: they can convert spinning energy into the motion of water. So if you hook up a water turbine to an engine and turn it, it will push water. Only then you call it a propellor, like in the picture on the lower left.

Term.Title: What Happened at Fukushima
Term.Text:
On March 11th, 2011, an earthquake struck 60 miles off the coast of Japan. This earthquake, at magnitude 9.0, was the largest earthquake in Japanese history and one of the largest in human history. The nuclear reactors in Japan all weathered the quake well and shut down safely. So far, so good.

But then came the tsunami. When the plant was built, the government had estimated that the largest possible tsunami that could ever hit the plant was 19 feet high, and so the plant had seawalls high enough to stop such a tsunami. But the tsunami that hit was actually 46 feet high. The water went right over the seawalls and into the plant area, flooding everything. Powerlines to the plant were all knocked out. All the diesel emergency generators that were designed to provide emergency power in case outside power was lost were inundated and rendered inoperable by the seawater. There were two emergency diesel generators at a higher elevation, but their wiring ran though the basement of the reactors and was flooded. The electrical pumps that supplied cooling water to the reactors were also flooded and ruined.

The plant was also equipped with huge batteries that kept vital systems running for three hours, but by the time the batteries ran out of juice, there was still no external power. Long stretches of power lines to the plant had been destroyed; even the roads leading to the plant were damaged or clogged with debris. Help wasn't able to arrive anytime soon.

The reactors had all been shut down safely but the decay heat still required large amounts of cooling water. There were no working pumps to supply that water, so the reactor cores steadily grew hotter and hotter. Eventually, three of the six reactor cores partially melted down.

But the fun had just started. When a reactor overheats, a chemical reaction between the cooling water and the fuel rods generates lots of free hydrogen gas. That hydrogen gas seeped out of the primary containment structure, a huge concrete and steel box that is supposed to keep everything inside even in a bad accident. The hydrogen gas collected in the upper portion of the secondary containment structure, which is actually pretty flimsy. Eventually something – a spark perhaps, or maybe a superheated piece of metal – ignited the hydrogen, and there was a big explosion, shown in the photograph. This was not a nuclear explosion, but it was big enough to shatter the secondary containment structure.

This did NOT release the radioactive materials inside the core of the reactor. Those materials are inside a huge steel vessel, and we believe that all three vessels pretty much held through the explosion. When the reactors did partially melt hours later, the pressure vessels succeeded in holding most of the molten radioactive stuff inside, but we believe that some of the liquid mess dropped down into the bottom the containment building. This stuff is intensely radioactive and very hot; if it had been blown out of the containment building there would have been enormous amounts of radioactivity released. It appears that this did not happen; most of what escaped was gaseous.

But it got even worse. Once the electricity to the power plant was lost, there were no pumps to keep pumping more cooling water into the spent fuel pools. The water got hotter and hotter, and after a few days, all the water had boiled away. Without cooling water, the old fuel rods started to get really hot, and eventually they caught fire. The smoke from that fire was extremely radioactive, and the wind carried that smoke away from the power plant. Luckily for us, most of the smoke blew out to sea, but some of it went over parts of Japan, dropping radioactive contamination. The smoke from the burning fuel rods in the spent fuel pools was probably the biggest source of release of radioactivity.

They've been measuring the radioactivity in various parts of Japan and it looks as if the worst radioactivity was kept pretty close to the plant. The safety evacuation zone, covering everything within 12 miles of the plant, will probably remain uninhabitable for at least five years. We're still gathering data, so none of this is certain.

Does the Fukushima accident prove that nuclear power plants are unsafe? It's not reasonable to extrapolate from the Fukushima plants to the hundreds of other nuclear plants around the world, but a few lessons do emerge: 1) the reactors were able to function properly through an earthquake much more powerful than anybody ever expected; 2) they were not able to function properly when hit with a 46-foot high tsunami; 3) the backup systems that are supposed to handle even worst-case situations were not able to prevent a serious release of radioactivity. If you're pro-nuclear, you can argue that nuclear power plants that are not vulnerable to 46-foot high tsunamis are still safe. If you're anti-nuclear, you can argue that the back-up safety systems were not good enough to handle an unexpected event. And if you're in the middle, the only conclusion you can draw is that nuclear power plants can indeed be dangerous in extremely unlikely situations.

Term.Title: Windows
Term.Text:
The picture on the right is an infrared photograph of a house on a cold night. The red areas are hotspots where heat is escaping from the house; green and blue are cooler areas where little heat is escaping. Notice how most of the heat is escaping through the windows. Most of your heating bill (and your cooling bill, too!) goes to transmit heat through your windows into the great outdoors.

If you live in a cold area, your windows should be double-glazed (have two panes of glass instead of just one, with an air space between them). Even better, install some sort of window covering: drapes, curtains, or some other fabric that keeps the air close to the window from mixing with the air in the house. This is especially important if you have a central air heating system with an air vent that blows air right over the window. That is meant to prevent water condensation on the window, but drapes do a better job and don't waste energy.
Another place to look: are there air leaks at doors and windows? It's easy to check: when it's cold outside, run your fingers along the edges of every outside door and window. If you can feel a cold draft, then you need to replace the weatherstripping along that door or window. Hardware stores sell all sorts of different weatherstripping products, so many that you'll probably be confused. Ask for help.
